39def _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds):
40 """
41 Remove the optimizer-related keyword arguments 'loc', 'scale' and
42 'optimizer' from `kwds`. Then check that `kwds` is empty, and
43 raise `TypeError("Unknown arguments: %s." % kwds)` if it is not.
44
45 This function is used in the fit method of distributions that override
46 the default method and do not use the default optimization code.
47
48 `kwds` is modified in-place.
49 """
50 kwds.pop('loc', None)
51 kwds.pop('scale', None)
52 kwds.pop('optimizer', None)
53 kwds.pop('method', None)
54 if kwds:
55 raise TypeError("Unknown arguments: %s." % kwds)
56
57
58def _call_super_mom(fun):
59 # If fit method is overridden only for MLE and doesn't specify what to do
60 # if method == 'mm' or with censored data, this decorator calls the generic
61 # implementation.
62 @wraps(fun)
63 def wrapper(self, data, *args, **kwds):
64 method = kwds.get('method', 'mle').lower()
65 censored = isinstance(data, CensoredData)
66 if method == 'mm' or (censored and data.num_censored() > 0):
67 return super(type(self), self).fit(data, *args, **kwds)
68 else:
69 if censored:
70 # data is an instance of CensoredData, but actually holds
71 # no censored values, so replace it with the array of
72 # uncensored values.
73 data = data._uncensored
74 return fun(self, data, *args, **kwds)
75
76 return wrapper
77
78
79def _get_left_bracket(fun, rbrack, lbrack=None):
80 # find left bracket for `root_scalar`. A guess for lbrack may be provided.
81 lbrack = lbrack or rbrack - 1
82 diff = rbrack - lbrack
83
84 # if there is no sign change in `fun` between the brackets, expand
85 # rbrack - lbrack until a sign change occurs
86 def interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack):
87 # return true if the signs disagree.
88 return np.sign(fun(lbrack)) != np.sign(fun(rbrack))
89
90 while not interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack):
91 diff *= 2
92 lbrack = rbrack - diff
93
94 msg = ("The solver could not find a bracket containing a "
95 "root to an MLE first order condition.")
96 if np.isinf(lbrack):
97 raise FitSolverError(msg)
98
99 return lbrack
100
101
102class ksone_gen(rv_continuous):
103 r"""Kolmogorov-Smirnov one-sided test statistic distribution.
104
105 This is the distribution of the one-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS)
106 statistics :math:`D_n^+` and :math:`D_n^-`
107 for a finite sample size ``n >= 1`` (the shape parameter).
108
109 %(before_notes)s
110
111 See Also
112 --------
113 kstwobign, kstwo, kstest
114
115 Notes
116 -----
117 :math:`D_n^+` and :math:`D_n^-` are given by
118
119 .. math::
120
121 D_n^+ &= \text{sup}_x (F_n(x) - F(x)),\\
122 D_n^- &= \text{sup}_x (F(x) - F_n(x)),\\
123
124 where :math:`F` is a continuous CDF and :math:`F_n` is an empirical CDF.
125 `ksone` describes the distribution under the null hypothesis of the KS test
126 that the empirical CDF corresponds to :math:`n` i.i.d. random variates
127 with CDF :math:`F`.
128
129 %(after_notes)s
130
131 References
132 ----------
133 .. [1] Birnbaum, Z. W. and Tingey, F.H. "One-sided confidence contours
134 for probability distribution functions", The Annals of Mathematical
135 Statistics, 22(4), pp 592-596 (1951).
136
137 %(example)s
138
139 """
140 def _argcheck(self, n):
141 return (n >= 1) & (n == np.round(n))
142
143 def _shape_info(self):
144 return [_ShapeInfo("n", True, (1, np.inf), (True, False))]
145
146 def _pdf(self, x, n):
147 return -scu._smirnovp(n, x)
148
149 def _cdf(self, x, n):
150 return scu._smirnovc(n, x)
151
152 def _sf(self, x, n):
153 return sc.smirnov(n, x)
154
155 def _ppf(self, q, n):
156 return scu._smirnovci(n, q)
157
158 def _isf(self, q, n):
159 return sc.smirnovi(n, q)
160
161
162ksone = ksone_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='ksone')
163
164
165class kstwo_gen(rv_continuous):
166 r"""Kolmogorov-Smirnov two-sided test statistic distribution.
167
168 This is the distribution of the two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS)
169 statistic :math:`D_n` for a finite sample size ``n >= 1``
170 (the shape parameter).
171
172 %(before_notes)s
173
174 See Also
175 --------
176 kstwobign, ksone, kstest
177
178 Notes
179 -----
180 :math:`D_n` is given by
181
182 .. math::
183
184 D_n = \text{sup}_x |F_n(x) - F(x)|
185
186 where :math:`F` is a (continuous) CDF and :math:`F_n` is an empirical CDF.
187 `kstwo` describes the distribution under the null hypothesis of the KS test
188 that the empirical CDF corresponds to :math:`n` i.i.d. random variates
189 with CDF :math:`F`.
190
191 %(after_notes)s
192
193 References
194 ----------
195 .. [1] Simard, R., L'Ecuyer, P. "Computing the Two-Sided
196 Kolmogorov-Smirnov Distribution", Journal of Statistical Software,
197 Vol 39, 11, 1-18 (2011).
198
199 %(example)s
200
201 """
202 def _argcheck(self, n):
203 return (n >= 1) & (n == np.round(n))
204
205 def _shape_info(self):
206 return [_ShapeInfo("n", True, (1, np.inf), (True, False))]
207
208 def _get_support(self, n):
209 return (0.5/(n if not isinstance(n, Iterable) else np.asanyarray(n)),
210 1.0)
211
212 def _pdf(self, x, n):
213 return kolmognp(n, x)
214
215 def _cdf(self, x, n):
216 return kolmogn(n, x)
217
218 def _sf(self, x, n):
219 return kolmogn(n, x, cdf=False)
220
221 def _ppf(self, q, n):
222 return kolmogni(n, q, cdf=True)
223
224 def _isf(self, q, n):
225 return kolmogni(n, q, cdf=False)
226
227
228# Use the pdf, (not the ppf) to compute moments
229kstwo = kstwo_gen(momtype=0, a=0.0, b=1.0, name='kstwo')
230
231
232class kstwobign_gen(rv_continuous):
233 r"""Limiting distribution of scaled Kolmogorov-Smirnov two-sided test statistic.
234
235 This is the asymptotic distribution of the two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov
236 statistic :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n` that measures the maximum absolute
237 distance of the theoretical (continuous) CDF from the empirical CDF.
238 (see `kstest`).
239
240 %(before_notes)s
241
242 See Also
243 --------
244 ksone, kstwo, kstest
245
246 Notes
247 -----
248 :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n` is given by
249
250 .. math::
251
252 D_n = \text{sup}_x |F_n(x) - F(x)|
253
254 where :math:`F` is a continuous CDF and :math:`F_n` is an empirical CDF.
255 `kstwobign` describes the asymptotic distribution (i.e. the limit of
256 :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n`) under the null hypothesis of the KS test that the
257 empirical CDF corresponds to i.i.d. random variates with CDF :math:`F`.
258
259 %(after_notes)s
260
261 References
262 ----------
263 .. [1] Feller, W. "On the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Limit Theorems for Empirical
264 Distributions", Ann. Math. Statist. Vol 19, 177-189 (1948).
265
266 %(example)s
267
268 """
269 def _shape_info(self):
270 return []
271
272 def _pdf(self, x):
273 return -scu._kolmogp(x)
274
275 def _cdf(self, x):
276 return scu._kolmogc(x)
277
278 def _sf(self, x):
279 return sc.kolmogorov(x)
280
281 def _ppf(self, q):
282 return scu._kolmogci(q)
283
284 def _isf(self, q):
285 return sc.kolmogi(q)
286
287
288kstwobign = kstwobign_gen(a=0.0, name='kstwobign')
289
290
291
292
293# loc = mu, scale = std
294# Keep these implementations out of the class definition so they can be reused
295# by other distributions.
296_norm_pdf_C = np.sqrt(2*np.pi)
297_norm_pdf_logC = np.log(_norm_pdf_C)
298
299
300def _norm_pdf(x):
301 return np.exp(-x**2/2.0) / _norm_pdf_C
302
303
304def _norm_logpdf(x):
305 return -x**2 / 2.0 - _norm_pdf_logC
306
307
308def _norm_cdf(x):
309 return sc.ndtr(x)
310
311
312def _norm_logcdf(x):
313 return sc.log_ndtr(x)
314
315
316def _norm_ppf(q):
317 return sc.ndtri(q)
318
319
320def _norm_sf(x):
321 return _norm_cdf(-x)
322
323
324def _norm_logsf(x):
325 return _norm_logcdf(-x)
326
327
328def _norm_isf(q):
329 return -_norm_ppf(q)
330
331
332class norm_gen(rv_continuous):
333 r"""A normal continuous random variable.
334
335 The location (``loc``) keyword specifies the mean.
336 The scale (``scale``) keyword specifies the standard deviation.
337
338 %(before_notes)s
339
340 Notes
341 -----
342 The probability density function for `norm` is:
343
344 .. math::
345
346 f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x^2/2)}{\sqrt{2\pi}}
347
348 for a real number :math:`x`.
349
350 %(after_notes)s
351
352 %(example)s
353
354 """
355 def _shape_info(self):
356 return []
357
358 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
359 return random_state.standard_normal(size)
360
361 def _pdf(self, x):
362 # norm.pdf(x) = exp(-x**2/2)/sqrt(2*pi)
363 return _norm_pdf(x)
364
365 def _logpdf(self, x):
366 return _norm_logpdf(x)
367
368 def _cdf(self, x):
369 return _norm_cdf(x)
370
371 def _logcdf(self, x):
372 return _norm_logcdf(x)
373
374 def _sf(self, x):
375 return _norm_sf(x)
376
377 def _logsf(self, x):
378 return _norm_logsf(x)
379
380 def _ppf(self, q):
381 return _norm_ppf(q)
382
383 def _isf(self, q):
384 return _norm_isf(q)
385
386 def _stats(self):
387 return 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0
388
389 def _entropy(self):
390 return 0.5*(np.log(2*np.pi)+1)
391
392 @_call_super_mom
393 @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
394 For the normal distribution, method of moments and maximum likelihood
395 estimation give identical fits, and explicit formulas for the estimates
396 are available.
397 This function uses these explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood
398 estimation of the normal distribution parameters, so the
399 `optimizer` and `method` arguments are ignored.\n\n""")
400 def fit(self, data, **kwds):
401 floc = kwds.pop('floc', None)
402 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None)
403
404 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds)
405
406 if floc is not None and fscale is not None:
407 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
408 # Without this check, this function would just return the
409 # parameters that were given.
410 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
411 "optimize.")
412
413 data = np.asarray(data)
414
415 if not np.isfinite(data).all():
416 raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
417
418 if floc is None:
419 loc = data.mean()
420 else:
421 loc = floc
422
423 if fscale is None:
424 scale = np.sqrt(((data - loc)**2).mean())
425 else:
426 scale = fscale
427
428 return loc, scale
429
430 def _munp(self, n):
431 """
432 @returns Moments of standard normal distribution for integer n >= 0
433
434 See eq. 16 of https://arxiv.org/abs/1209.4340v2
435 """
436 if n % 2 == 0:
437 return sc.factorial2(n - 1)
438 else:
439 return 0.
440
441
442norm = norm_gen(name='norm')
443
444
445class alpha_gen(rv_continuous):
446 r"""An alpha continuous random variable.
447
448 %(before_notes)s
449
450 Notes
451 -----
452 The probability density function for `alpha` ([1]_, [2]_) is:
453
454 .. math::
455
456 f(x, a) = \frac{1}{x^2 \Phi(a) \sqrt{2\pi}} *
457 \exp(-\frac{1}{2} (a-1/x)^2)
458
459 where :math:`\Phi` is the normal CDF, :math:`x > 0`, and :math:`a > 0`.
460
461 `alpha` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter.
462
463 %(after_notes)s
464
465 References
466 ----------
467 .. [1] Johnson, Kotz, and Balakrishnan, "Continuous Univariate
468 Distributions, Volume 1", Second Edition, John Wiley and Sons,
469 p. 173 (1994).
470 .. [2] Anthony A. Salvia, "Reliability applications of the Alpha
471 Distribution", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Vol. R-34,
472 No. 3, pp. 251-252 (1985).
473
474 %(example)s
475
476 """
477 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
478
479 def _shape_info(self):
480 return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
481
482 def _pdf(self, x, a):
483 # alpha.pdf(x, a) = 1/(x**2*Phi(a)*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2 * (a-1/x)**2)
484 return 1.0/(x**2)/_norm_cdf(a)*_norm_pdf(a-1.0/x)
485
486 def _logpdf(self, x, a):
487 return -2*np.log(x) + _norm_logpdf(a-1.0/x) - np.log(_norm_cdf(a))
488
489 def _cdf(self, x, a):
490 return _norm_cdf(a-1.0/x) / _norm_cdf(a)
491
492 def _ppf(self, q, a):
493 return 1.0/np.asarray(a - _norm_ppf(q*_norm_cdf(a)))
494
495 def _stats(self, a):
496 return [np.inf]*2 + [np.nan]*2
497
498
499alpha = alpha_gen(a=0.0, name='alpha')
500
501
502class anglit_gen(rv_continuous):
503 r"""An anglit continuous random variable.
504
505 %(before_notes)s
506
507 Notes
508 -----
509 The probability density function for `anglit` is:
510
511 .. math::
512
513 f(x) = \sin(2x + \pi/2) = \cos(2x)
514
515 for :math:`-\pi/4 \le x \le \pi/4`.
516
517 %(after_notes)s
518
519 %(example)s
520
521 """
522 def _shape_info(self):
523 return []
524
525 def _pdf(self, x):
526 # anglit.pdf(x) = sin(2*x + \pi/2) = cos(2*x)
527 return np.cos(2*x)
528
529 def _cdf(self, x):
530 return np.sin(x+np.pi/4)**2.0
531
532 def _sf(self, x):
533 return np.cos(x + np.pi / 4) ** 2.0
534
535 def _ppf(self, q):
536 return np.arcsin(np.sqrt(q))-np.pi/4
537
538 def _stats(self):
539 return 0.0, np.pi*np.pi/16-0.5, 0.0, -2*(np.pi**4 - 96)/(np.pi*np.pi-8)**2
540
541 def _entropy(self):
542 return 1-np.log(2)
543
544
545anglit = anglit_gen(a=-np.pi/4, b=np.pi/4, name='anglit')
546
547
548class arcsine_gen(rv_continuous):
549 r"""An arcsine continuous random variable.
550
551 %(before_notes)s
552
553 Notes
554 -----
555 The probability density function for `arcsine` is:
556
557 .. math::
558
559 f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi \sqrt{x (1-x)}}
560
561 for :math:`0 < x < 1`.
562
563 %(after_notes)s
564
565 %(example)s
566
567 """
568 def _shape_info(self):
569 return []
570
571 def _pdf(self, x):
572 # arcsine.pdf(x) = 1/(pi*sqrt(x*(1-x)))
573 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
574 return 1.0/np.pi/np.sqrt(x*(1-x))
575
576 def _cdf(self, x):
577 return 2.0/np.pi*np.arcsin(np.sqrt(x))
578
579 def _ppf(self, q):
580 return np.sin(np.pi/2.0*q)**2.0
581
582 def _stats(self):
583 mu = 0.5
584 mu2 = 1.0/8
585 g1 = 0
586 g2 = -3.0/2.0
587 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
588
589 def _entropy(self):
590 return -0.24156447527049044468
591
592
593arcsine = arcsine_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='arcsine')
594
595
596class FitDataError(ValueError):
597 """Raised when input data is inconsistent with fixed parameters."""
598 # This exception is raised by, for example, beta_gen.fit when both floc
599 # and fscale are fixed and there are values in the data not in the open
600 # interval (floc, floc+fscale).
601 def __init__(self, distr, lower, upper):
602 self.args = (
603 "Invalid values in `data`. Maximum likelihood "
604 "estimation with {distr!r} requires that {lower!r} < "
605 "(x - loc)/scale < {upper!r} for each x in `data`.".format(
606 distr=distr, lower=lower, upper=upper),
607 )
608
609
610class FitSolverError(FitError):
611 """
612 Raised when a solver fails to converge while fitting a distribution.
613 """
614 # This exception is raised by, for example, beta_gen.fit when
615 # optimize.fsolve returns with ier != 1.
616 def __init__(self, mesg):
617 emsg = "Solver for the MLE equations failed to converge: "
618 emsg += mesg.replace('\n', '')
619 self.args = (emsg,)
620
621
622def _beta_mle_a(a, b, n, s1):
623 # The zeros of this function give the MLE for `a`, with
624 # `b`, `n` and `s1` given. `s1` is the sum of the logs of
625 # the data. `n` is the number of data points.
626 psiab = sc.psi(a + b)
627 func = s1 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(a))
628 return func
629
630
631def _beta_mle_ab(theta, n, s1, s2):
632 # Zeros of this function are critical points of
633 # the maximum likelihood function. Solving this system
634 # for theta (which contains a and b) gives the MLE for a and b
635 # given `n`, `s1` and `s2`. `s1` is the sum of the logs of the data,
636 # and `s2` is the sum of the logs of 1 - data. `n` is the number
637 # of data points.
638 a, b = theta
639 psiab = sc.psi(a + b)
640 func = [s1 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(a)),
641 s2 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(b))]
642 return func
643
644
645class beta_gen(rv_continuous):
646 r"""A beta continuous random variable.
647
648 %(before_notes)s
649
650 Notes
651 -----
652 The probability density function for `beta` is:
653
654 .. math::
655
656 f(x, a, b) = \frac{\Gamma(a+b) x^{a-1} (1-x)^{b-1}}
657 {\Gamma(a) \Gamma(b)}
658
659 for :math:`0 <= x <= 1`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`b > 0`, where
660 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`).
661
662 `beta` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters.
663
664 %(after_notes)s
665
666 %(example)s
667
668 """
669 def _shape_info(self):
670 ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
671 ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
672 return [ia, ib]
673
674 def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
675 return random_state.beta(a, b, size)
676
677 def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
678 # gamma(a+b) * x**(a-1) * (1-x)**(b-1)
679 # beta.pdf(x, a, b) = ------------------------------------
680 # gamma(a)*gamma(b)
681 with np.errstate(over='ignore'):
682 return _boost._beta_pdf(x, a, b)
683
684 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b):
685 lPx = sc.xlog1py(b - 1.0, -x) + sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, x)
686 lPx -= sc.betaln(a, b)
687 return lPx
688
689 def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
690 return _boost._beta_cdf(x, a, b)
691
692 def _sf(self, x, a, b):
693 return _boost._beta_sf(x, a, b)
694
695 def _isf(self, x, a, b):
696 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
697 return _boost._beta_isf(x, a, b)
698
699 def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
700 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
701 return _boost._beta_ppf(q, a, b)
702
703 def _stats(self, a, b):
704 return (
705 _boost._beta_mean(a, b),
706 _boost._beta_variance(a, b),
707 _boost._beta_skewness(a, b),
708 _boost._beta_kurtosis_excess(a, b))
709
710 def _fitstart(self, data):
711 if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
712 data = data._uncensor()
713
714 g1 = _skew(data)
715 g2 = _kurtosis(data)
716
717 def func(x):
718 a, b = x
719 sk = 2*(b-a)*np.sqrt(a + b + 1) / (a + b + 2) / np.sqrt(a*b)
720 ku = a**3 - a**2*(2*b-1) + b**2*(b+1) - 2*a*b*(b+2)
721 ku /= a*b*(a+b+2)*(a+b+3)
722 ku *= 6
723 return [sk-g1, ku-g2]
724 a, b = optimize.fsolve(func, (1.0, 1.0))
725 return super()._fitstart(data, args=(a, b))
726
727 @_call_super_mom
728 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
729 In the special case where `method="MLE"` and
730 both `floc` and `fscale` are given, a
731 `ValueError` is raised if any value `x` in `data` does not satisfy
732 `floc < x < floc + fscale`.\n\n""")
733 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
734 # Override rv_continuous.fit, so we can more efficiently handle the
735 # case where floc and fscale are given.
736
737 floc = kwds.get('floc', None)
738 fscale = kwds.get('fscale', None)
739
740 if floc is None or fscale is None:
741 # do general fit
742 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
743
744 # We already got these from kwds, so just pop them.
745 kwds.pop('floc', None)
746 kwds.pop('fscale', None)
747
748 f0 = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, ['f0', 'fa', 'fix_a'])
749 f1 = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, ['f1', 'fb', 'fix_b'])
750
751 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds)
752
753 if f0 is not None and f1 is not None:
754 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
755 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
756 "optimize.")
757
758 # Special case: loc and scale are constrained, so we are fitting
759 # just the shape parameters. This can be done much more efficiently
760 # than the method used in `rv_continuous.fit`. (See the subsection
761 # "Two unknown parameters" in the section "Maximum likelihood" of
762 # the Wikipedia article on the Beta distribution for the formulas.)
763
764 if not np.isfinite(data).all():
765 raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
766
767 # Normalize the data to the interval [0, 1].
768 data = (np.ravel(data) - floc) / fscale
769 if np.any(data <= 0) or np.any(data >= 1):
770 raise FitDataError("beta", lower=floc, upper=floc + fscale)
771
772 xbar = data.mean()
773
774 if f0 is not None or f1 is not None:
775 # One of the shape parameters is fixed.
776
777 if f0 is not None:
778 # The shape parameter a is fixed, so swap the parameters
779 # and flip the data. We always solve for `a`. The result
780 # will be swapped back before returning.
781 b = f0
782 data = 1 - data
783 xbar = 1 - xbar
784 else:
785 b = f1
786
787 # Initial guess for a. Use the formula for the mean of the beta
788 # distribution, E[x] = a / (a + b), to generate a reasonable
789 # starting point based on the mean of the data and the given
790 # value of b.
791 a = b * xbar / (1 - xbar)
792
793 # Compute the MLE for `a` by solving _beta_mle_a.
794 theta, info, ier, mesg = optimize.fsolve(
795 _beta_mle_a, a,
796 args=(b, len(data), np.log(data).sum()),
797 full_output=True
798 )
799 if ier != 1:
800 raise FitSolverError(mesg=mesg)
801 a = theta[0]
802
803 if f0 is not None:
804 # The shape parameter a was fixed, so swap back the
805 # parameters.
806 a, b = b, a
807
808 else:
809 # Neither of the shape parameters is fixed.
810
811 # s1 and s2 are used in the extra arguments passed to _beta_mle_ab
812 # by optimize.fsolve.
813 s1 = np.log(data).sum()
814 s2 = sc.log1p(-data).sum()
815
816 # Use the "method of moments" to estimate the initial
817 # guess for a and b.
818 fac = xbar * (1 - xbar) / data.var(ddof=0) - 1
819 a = xbar * fac
820 b = (1 - xbar) * fac
821
822 # Compute the MLE for a and b by solving _beta_mle_ab.
823 theta, info, ier, mesg = optimize.fsolve(
824 _beta_mle_ab, [a, b],
825 args=(len(data), s1, s2),
826 full_output=True
827 )
828 if ier != 1:
829 raise FitSolverError(mesg=mesg)
830 a, b = theta
831
832 return a, b, floc, fscale
833
834 def _entropy(self, a, b):
835 return (sc.betaln(a, b) - (a - 1) * sc.psi(a) -
836 (b - 1) * sc.psi(b) + (a + b - 2) * sc.psi(a + b))
837
838
839beta = beta_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='beta')
840
841
842class betaprime_gen(rv_continuous):
843 r"""A beta prime continuous random variable.
844
845 %(before_notes)s
846
847 Notes
848 -----
849 The probability density function for `betaprime` is:
850
851 .. math::
852
853 f(x, a, b) = \frac{x^{a-1} (1+x)^{-a-b}}{\beta(a, b)}
854
855 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`b > 0`, where
856 :math:`\beta(a, b)` is the beta function (see `scipy.special.beta`).
857
858 `betaprime` takes ``a`` and ``b`` as shape parameters.
859
860 The distribution is related to the `beta` distribution as follows:
861 If :math:`X` follows a beta distribution with parameters :math:`a, b`,
862 then :math:`Y = X/(1-X)` has a beta prime distribution with
863 parameters :math:`a, b` ([1]_).
864
865 The beta prime distribution is a reparametrized version of the
866 F distribution. The beta prime distribution with shape parameters
867 ``a`` and ``b`` and ``scale = s`` is equivalent to the F distribution
868 with parameters ``d1 = 2*a``, ``d2 = 2*b`` and ``scale = (a/b)*s``.
869 For example,
870
871 >>> from scipy.stats import betaprime, f
872 >>> x = [1, 2, 5, 10]
873 >>> a = 12
874 >>> b = 5
875 >>> betaprime.pdf(x, a, b, scale=2)
876 array([0.00541179, 0.08331299, 0.14669185, 0.03150079])
877 >>> f.pdf(x, 2*a, 2*b, scale=(a/b)*2)
878 array([0.00541179, 0.08331299, 0.14669185, 0.03150079])
879
880 %(after_notes)s
881
882 References
883 ----------
884 .. [1] Beta prime distribution, Wikipedia,
885 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_prime_distribution
886
887 %(example)s
888
889 """
890 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
891
892 def _shape_info(self):
893 ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
894 ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
895 return [ia, ib]
896
897 def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
898 u1 = gamma.rvs(a, size=size, random_state=random_state)
899 u2 = gamma.rvs(b, size=size, random_state=random_state)
900 return u1 / u2
901
902 def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
903 # betaprime.pdf(x, a, b) = x**(a-1) * (1+x)**(-a-b) / beta(a, b)
904 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, b))
905
906 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b):
907 return sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, x) - sc.xlog1py(a + b, x) - sc.betaln(a, b)
908
909 def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
910 # note: f2 is the direct way to compute the cdf if the relationship
911 # to the beta distribution is used.
912 # however, for very large x, x/(1+x) == 1. since the distribution
913 # has very fat tails if b is small, this can cause inaccurate results
914 # use the following relationship of the incomplete beta function:
915 # betainc(x, a, b) = 1 - betainc(1-x, b, a)
916 # see gh-17631
917 return _lazywhere(
918 x > 1, [x, a, b],
919 lambda x_, a_, b_: beta._sf(1/(1+x_), b_, a_),
920 f2=lambda x_, a_, b_: beta._cdf(x_/(1+x_), a_, b_))
921
922 def _sf(self, x, a, b):
923 return _lazywhere(
924 x > 1, [x, a, b],
925 lambda x_, a_, b_: beta._cdf(1/(1+x_), b_, a_),
926 f2=lambda x_, a_, b_: beta._sf(x_/(1+x_), a_, b_)
927 )
928
929 def _ppf(self, p, a, b):
930 p, a, b = np.broadcast_arrays(p, a, b)
931 # by default, compute compute the ppf by solving the following:
932 # p = beta._cdf(x/(1+x), a, b). This implies x = r/(1-r) with
933 # r = beta._ppf(p, a, b). This can cause numerical issues if r is
934 # very close to 1. in that case, invert the alternative expression of
935 # the cdf: p = beta._sf(1/(1+x), b, a).
936 r = stats.beta._ppf(p, a, b)
937 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
938 out = r / (1 - r)
939 i = (r > 0.9999)
940 out[i] = 1/stats.beta._isf(p[i], b[i], a[i]) - 1
941 return out
942
943 def _munp(self, n, a, b):
944 return _lazywhere(
945 b > n, (a, b),
946 lambda a, b: np.prod([(a+i-1)/(b-i) for i in range(1, n+1)], axis=0),
947 fillvalue=np.inf)
948
949
950betaprime = betaprime_gen(a=0.0, name='betaprime')
951
952
953class bradford_gen(rv_continuous):
954 r"""A Bradford continuous random variable.
955
956 %(before_notes)s
957
958 Notes
959 -----
960 The probability density function for `bradford` is:
961
962 .. math::
963
964 f(x, c) = \frac{c}{\log(1+c) (1+cx)}
965
966 for :math:`0 <= x <= 1` and :math:`c > 0`.
967
968 `bradford` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
969
970 %(after_notes)s
971
972 %(example)s
973
974 """
975 def _shape_info(self):
976 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
977
978 def _pdf(self, x, c):
979 # bradford.pdf(x, c) = c / (k * (1+c*x))
980 return c / (c*x + 1.0) / sc.log1p(c)
981
982 def _cdf(self, x, c):
983 return sc.log1p(c*x) / sc.log1p(c)
984
985 def _ppf(self, q, c):
986 return sc.expm1(q * sc.log1p(c)) / c
987
988 def _stats(self, c, moments='mv'):
989 k = np.log(1.0+c)
990 mu = (c-k)/(c*k)
991 mu2 = ((c+2.0)*k-2.0*c)/(2*c*k*k)
992 g1 = None
993 g2 = None
994 if 's' in moments:
995 g1 = np.sqrt(2)*(12*c*c-9*c*k*(c+2)+2*k*k*(c*(c+3)+3))
996 g1 /= np.sqrt(c*(c*(k-2)+2*k))*(3*c*(k-2)+6*k)
997 if 'k' in moments:
998 g2 = (c**3*(k-3)*(k*(3*k-16)+24)+12*k*c*c*(k-4)*(k-3) +
999 6*c*k*k*(3*k-14) + 12*k**3)
1000 g2 /= 3*c*(c*(k-2)+2*k)**2
1001 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
1002
1003 def _entropy(self, c):
1004 k = np.log(1+c)
1005 return k/2.0 - np.log(c/k)
1006
1007
1008bradford = bradford_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='bradford')
1009
1010
1011class burr_gen(rv_continuous):
1012 r"""A Burr (Type III) continuous random variable.
1013
1014 %(before_notes)s
1015
1016 See Also
1017 --------
1018 fisk : a special case of either `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1``
1019 burr12 : Burr Type XII distribution
1020 mielke : Mielke Beta-Kappa / Dagum distribution
1021
1022 Notes
1023 -----
1024 The probability density function for `burr` is:
1025
1026 .. math::
1027
1028 f(x; c, d) = c d \frac{x^{-c - 1}}
1029 {{(1 + x^{-c})}^{d + 1}}
1030
1031 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c, d > 0`.
1032
1033 `burr` takes ``c`` and ``d`` as shape parameters for :math:`c` and
1034 :math:`d`.
1035
1036 This is the PDF corresponding to the third CDF given in Burr's list;
1037 specifically, it is equation (11) in Burr's paper [1]_. The distribution
1038 is also commonly referred to as the Dagum distribution [2]_. If the
1039 parameter :math:`c < 1` then the mean of the distribution does not
1040 exist and if :math:`c < 2` the variance does not exist [2]_.
1041 The PDF is finite at the left endpoint :math:`x = 0` if :math:`c * d >= 1`.
1042
1043 %(after_notes)s
1044
1045 References
1046 ----------
1047 .. [1] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of
1048 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942).
1049 .. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dagum_distribution
1050 .. [3] Kleiber, Christian. "A guide to the Dagum distributions."
1051 Modeling Income Distributions and Lorenz Curves pp 97-117 (2008).
1052
1053 %(example)s
1054
1055 """
1056 # Do not set _support_mask to rv_continuous._open_support_mask
1057 # Whether the left-hand endpoint is suitable for pdf evaluation is dependent
1058 # on the values of c and d: if c*d >= 1, the pdf is finite, otherwise infinite.
1059
1060 def _shape_info(self):
1061 ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1062 id = _ShapeInfo("d", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1063 return [ic, id]
1064
1065 def _pdf(self, x, c, d):
1066 # burr.pdf(x, c, d) = c * d * x**(-c-1) * (1+x**(-c))**(-d-1)
1067 output = _lazywhere(
1068 x == 0, [x, c, d],
1069 lambda x_, c_, d_: c_ * d_ * (x_**(c_*d_-1)) / (1 + x_**c_),
1070 f2=lambda x_, c_, d_: (c_ * d_ * (x_ ** (-c_ - 1.0)) /
1071 ((1 + x_ ** (-c_)) ** (d_ + 1.0))))
1072 if output.ndim == 0:
1073 return output[()]
1074 return output
1075
1076 def _logpdf(self, x, c, d):
1077 output = _lazywhere(
1078 x == 0, [x, c, d],
1079 lambda x_, c_, d_: (np.log(c_) + np.log(d_) + sc.xlogy(c_*d_ - 1, x_)
1080 - (d_+1) * sc.log1p(x_**(c_))),
1081 f2=lambda x_, c_, d_: (np.log(c_) + np.log(d_)
1082 + sc.xlogy(-c_ - 1, x_)
1083 - sc.xlog1py(d_+1, x_**(-c_))))
1084 if output.ndim == 0:
1085 return output[()]
1086 return output
1087
1088 def _cdf(self, x, c, d):
1089 return (1 + x**(-c))**(-d)
1090
1091 def _logcdf(self, x, c, d):
1092 return sc.log1p(x**(-c)) * (-d)
1093
1094 def _sf(self, x, c, d):
1095 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c, d))
1096
1097 def _logsf(self, x, c, d):
1098 return np.log1p(- (1 + x**(-c))**(-d))
1099
1100 def _ppf(self, q, c, d):
1101 return (q**(-1.0/d) - 1)**(-1.0/c)
1102
1103 def _stats(self, c, d):
1104 nc = np.arange(1, 5).reshape(4,1) / c
1105 # ek is the kth raw moment, e1 is the mean e2-e1**2 variance etc.
1106 e1, e2, e3, e4 = sc.beta(d + nc, 1. - nc) * d
1107 mu = np.where(c > 1.0, e1, np.nan)
1108 mu2_if_c = e2 - mu**2
1109 mu2 = np.where(c > 2.0, mu2_if_c, np.nan)
1110 g1 = _lazywhere(
1111 c > 3.0,
1112 (c, e1, e2, e3, mu2_if_c),
1113 lambda c, e1, e2, e3, mu2_if_c: (e3 - 3*e2*e1 + 2*e1**3) / np.sqrt((mu2_if_c)**3),
1114 fillvalue=np.nan)
1115 g2 = _lazywhere(
1116 c > 4.0,
1117 (c, e1, e2, e3, e4, mu2_if_c),
1118 lambda c, e1, e2, e3, e4, mu2_if_c: (
1119 ((e4 - 4*e3*e1 + 6*e2*e1**2 - 3*e1**4) / mu2_if_c**2) - 3),
1120 fillvalue=np.nan)
1121 if np.ndim(c) == 0:
1122 return mu.item(), mu2.item(), g1.item(), g2.item()
1123 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
1124
1125 def _munp(self, n, c, d):
1126 def __munp(n, c, d):
1127 nc = 1. * n / c
1128 return d * sc.beta(1.0 - nc, d + nc)
1129 n, c, d = np.asarray(n), np.asarray(c), np.asarray(d)
1130 return _lazywhere((c > n) & (n == n) & (d == d), (c, d, n),
1131 lambda c, d, n: __munp(n, c, d),
1132 np.nan)
1133
1134
1135burr = burr_gen(a=0.0, name='burr')
1136
1137
1138class burr12_gen(rv_continuous):
1139 r"""A Burr (Type XII) continuous random variable.
1140
1141 %(before_notes)s
1142
1143 See Also
1144 --------
1145 fisk : a special case of either `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1``
1146 burr : Burr Type III distribution
1147
1148 Notes
1149 -----
1150 The probability density function for `burr12` is:
1151
1152 .. math::
1153
1154 f(x; c, d) = c d \frac{x^{c-1}}
1155 {(1 + x^c)^{d + 1}}
1156
1157 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c, d > 0`.
1158
1159 `burr12` takes ``c`` and ``d`` as shape parameters for :math:`c`
1160 and :math:`d`.
1161
1162 This is the PDF corresponding to the twelfth CDF given in Burr's list;
1163 specifically, it is equation (20) in Burr's paper [1]_.
1164
1165 %(after_notes)s
1166
1167 The Burr type 12 distribution is also sometimes referred to as
1168 the Singh-Maddala distribution from NIST [2]_.
1169
1170 References
1171 ----------
1172 .. [1] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of
1173 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942).
1174
1175 .. [2] https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/b12pdf.htm
1176
1177 .. [3] "Burr distribution",
1178 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burr_distribution
1179
1180 %(example)s
1181
1182 """
1183 def _shape_info(self):
1184 ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1185 id = _ShapeInfo("d", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1186 return [ic, id]
1187
1188 def _pdf(self, x, c, d):
1189 # burr12.pdf(x, c, d) = c * d * x**(c-1) * (1+x**(c))**(-d-1)
1190 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c, d))
1191
1192 def _logpdf(self, x, c, d):
1193 return np.log(c) + np.log(d) + sc.xlogy(c - 1, x) + sc.xlog1py(-d-1, x**c)
1194
1195 def _cdf(self, x, c, d):
1196 return -sc.expm1(self._logsf(x, c, d))
1197
1198 def _logcdf(self, x, c, d):
1199 return sc.log1p(-(1 + x**c)**(-d))
1200
1201 def _sf(self, x, c, d):
1202 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c, d))
1203
1204 def _logsf(self, x, c, d):
1205 return sc.xlog1py(-d, x**c)
1206
1207 def _ppf(self, q, c, d):
1208 # The following is an implementation of
1209 # ((1 - q)**(-1.0/d) - 1)**(1.0/c)
1210 # that does a better job handling small values of q.
1211 return sc.expm1(-1/d * sc.log1p(-q))**(1/c)
1212
1213 def _munp(self, n, c, d):
1214 nc = 1. * n / c
1215 return d * sc.beta(1.0 + nc, d - nc)
1216
1217
1218burr12 = burr12_gen(a=0.0, name='burr12')
1219
1220
1221class fisk_gen(burr_gen):
1222 r"""A Fisk continuous random variable.
1223
1224 The Fisk distribution is also known as the log-logistic distribution.
1225
1226 %(before_notes)s
1227
1228 See Also
1229 --------
1230 burr
1231
1232 Notes
1233 -----
1234 The probability density function for `fisk` is:
1235
1236 .. math::
1237
1238 f(x, c) = \frac{c x^{c-1}}
1239 {(1 + x^c)^2}
1240
1241 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c > 0`.
1242
1243 Please note that the above expression can be transformed into the following
1244 one, which is also commonly used:
1245
1246 .. math::
1247
1248 f(x, c) = \frac{c x^{-c-1}}
1249 {(1 + x^{-c})^2}
1250
1251 `fisk` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
1252
1253 `fisk` is a special case of `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1``.
1254
1255 %(after_notes)s
1256
1257 %(example)s
1258
1259 """
1260 def _shape_info(self):
1261 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1262
1263 def _pdf(self, x, c):
1264 # fisk.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * (1 + x**(-c))**(-2)
1265 return burr._pdf(x, c, 1.0)
1266
1267 def _cdf(self, x, c):
1268 return burr._cdf(x, c, 1.0)
1269
1270 def _sf(self, x, c):
1271 return burr._sf(x, c, 1.0)
1272
1273 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
1274 # fisk.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * (1 + x**(-c))**(-2)
1275 return burr._logpdf(x, c, 1.0)
1276
1277 def _logcdf(self, x, c):
1278 return burr._logcdf(x, c, 1.0)
1279
1280 def _logsf(self, x, c):
1281 return burr._logsf(x, c, 1.0)
1282
1283 def _ppf(self, x, c):
1284 return burr._ppf(x, c, 1.0)
1285
1286 def _munp(self, n, c):
1287 return burr._munp(n, c, 1.0)
1288
1289 def _stats(self, c):
1290 return burr._stats(c, 1.0)
1291
1292 def _entropy(self, c):
1293 return 2 - np.log(c)
1294
1295
1296fisk = fisk_gen(a=0.0, name='fisk')
1297
1298
1299class cauchy_gen(rv_continuous):
1300 r"""A Cauchy continuous random variable.
1301
1302 %(before_notes)s
1303
1304 Notes
1305 -----
1306 The probability density function for `cauchy` is
1307
1308 .. math::
1309
1310 f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi (1 + x^2)}
1311
1312 for a real number :math:`x`.
1313
1314 %(after_notes)s
1315
1316 %(example)s
1317
1318 """
1319 def _shape_info(self):
1320 return []
1321
1322 def _pdf(self, x):
1323 # cauchy.pdf(x) = 1 / (pi * (1 + x**2))
1324 return 1.0/np.pi/(1.0+x*x)
1325
1326 def _cdf(self, x):
1327 return 0.5 + 1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x)
1328
1329 def _ppf(self, q):
1330 return np.tan(np.pi*q-np.pi/2.0)
1331
1332 def _sf(self, x):
1333 return 0.5 - 1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x)
1334
1335 def _isf(self, q):
1336 return np.tan(np.pi/2.0-np.pi*q)
1337
1338 def _stats(self):
1339 return np.nan, np.nan, np.nan, np.nan
1340
1341 def _entropy(self):
1342 return np.log(4*np.pi)
1343
1344 def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
1345 # Initialize ML guesses using quartiles instead of moments.
1346 if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
1347 data = data._uncensor()
1348 p25, p50, p75 = np.percentile(data, [25, 50, 75])
1349 return p50, (p75 - p25)/2
1350
1351
1352cauchy = cauchy_gen(name='cauchy')
1353
1354
1355class chi_gen(rv_continuous):
1356 r"""A chi continuous random variable.
1357
1358 %(before_notes)s
1359
1360 Notes
1361 -----
1362 The probability density function for `chi` is:
1363
1364 .. math::
1365
1366 f(x, k) = \frac{1}{2^{k/2-1} \Gamma \left( k/2 \right)}
1367 x^{k-1} \exp \left( -x^2/2 \right)
1368
1369 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`k > 0` (degrees of freedom, denoted ``df``
1370 in the implementation). :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function
1371 (`scipy.special.gamma`).
1372
1373 Special cases of `chi` are:
1374
1375 - ``chi(1, loc, scale)`` is equivalent to `halfnorm`
1376 - ``chi(2, 0, scale)`` is equivalent to `rayleigh`
1377 - ``chi(3, 0, scale)`` is equivalent to `maxwell`
1378
1379 `chi` takes ``df`` as a shape parameter.
1380
1381 %(after_notes)s
1382
1383 %(example)s
1384
1385 """
1386 def _shape_info(self):
1387 return [_ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1388
1389 def _rvs(self, df, size=None, random_state=None):
1390 return np.sqrt(chi2.rvs(df, size=size, random_state=random_state))
1391
1392 def _pdf(self, x, df):
1393 # x**(df-1) * exp(-x**2/2)
1394 # chi.pdf(x, df) = -------------------------
1395 # 2**(df/2-1) * gamma(df/2)
1396 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, df))
1397
1398 def _logpdf(self, x, df):
1399 l = np.log(2) - .5*np.log(2)*df - sc.gammaln(.5*df)
1400 return l + sc.xlogy(df - 1., x) - .5*x**2
1401
1402 def _cdf(self, x, df):
1403 return sc.gammainc(.5*df, .5*x**2)
1404
1405 def _sf(self, x, df):
1406 return sc.gammaincc(.5*df, .5*x**2)
1407
1408 def _ppf(self, q, df):
1409 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammaincinv(.5*df, q))
1410
1411 def _isf(self, q, df):
1412 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammainccinv(.5*df, q))
1413
1414 def _stats(self, df):
1415 mu = np.sqrt(2)*np.exp(sc.gammaln(df/2.0+0.5)-sc.gammaln(df/2.0))
1416 mu2 = df - mu*mu
1417 g1 = (2*mu**3.0 + mu*(1-2*df))/np.asarray(np.power(mu2, 1.5))
1418 g2 = 2*df*(1.0-df)-6*mu**4 + 4*mu**2 * (2*df-1)
1419 g2 /= np.asarray(mu2**2.0)
1420 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
1421
1422 def _entropy(self, df):
1423
1424 def regular_formula(df):
1425 return (sc.gammaln(.5 * df)
1426 + 0.5 * (df - np.log(2) - (df - 1) * sc.digamma(0.5 * df)))
1427
1428 def asymptotic_formula(df):
1429 return (0.5 + np.log(np.pi)/2 - (df**-1)/6 - (df**-2)/6
1430 - 4/45*(df**-3) + (df**-4)/15)
1431
1432 return _lazywhere(df < 3e2, (df, ), regular_formula,
1433 f2=asymptotic_formula)
1434
1435
1436chi = chi_gen(a=0.0, name='chi')
1437
1438
1439class chi2_gen(rv_continuous):
1440 r"""A chi-squared continuous random variable.
1441
1442 For the noncentral chi-square distribution, see `ncx2`.
1443
1444 %(before_notes)s
1445
1446 See Also
1447 --------
1448 ncx2
1449
1450 Notes
1451 -----
1452 The probability density function for `chi2` is:
1453
1454 .. math::
1455
1456 f(x, k) = \frac{1}{2^{k/2} \Gamma \left( k/2 \right)}
1457 x^{k/2-1} \exp \left( -x/2 \right)
1458
1459 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`k > 0` (degrees of freedom, denoted ``df``
1460 in the implementation).
1461
1462 `chi2` takes ``df`` as a shape parameter.
1463
1464 The chi-squared distribution is a special case of the gamma
1465 distribution, with gamma parameters ``a = df/2``, ``loc = 0`` and
1466 ``scale = 2``.
1467
1468 %(after_notes)s
1469
1470 %(example)s
1471
1472 """
1473 def _shape_info(self):
1474 return [_ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1475
1476 def _rvs(self, df, size=None, random_state=None):
1477 return random_state.chisquare(df, size)
1478
1479 def _pdf(self, x, df):
1480 # chi2.pdf(x, df) = 1 / (2*gamma(df/2)) * (x/2)**(df/2-1) * exp(-x/2)
1481 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, df))
1482
1483 def _logpdf(self, x, df):
1484 return sc.xlogy(df/2.-1, x) - x/2. - sc.gammaln(df/2.) - (np.log(2)*df)/2.
1485
1486 def _cdf(self, x, df):
1487 return sc.chdtr(df, x)
1488
1489 def _sf(self, x, df):
1490 return sc.chdtrc(df, x)
1491
1492 def _isf(self, p, df):
1493 return sc.chdtri(df, p)
1494
1495 def _ppf(self, p, df):
1496 return 2*sc.gammaincinv(df/2, p)
1497
1498 def _stats(self, df):
1499 mu = df
1500 mu2 = 2*df
1501 g1 = 2*np.sqrt(2.0/df)
1502 g2 = 12.0/df
1503 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
1504
1505 def _entropy(self, df):
1506 half_df = 0.5 * df
1507
1508 def regular_formula(half_df):
1509 return (half_df + np.log(2) + sc.gammaln(half_df) +
1510 (1 - half_df) * sc.psi(half_df))
1511
1512 def asymptotic_formula(half_df):
1513 # plug in the above formula the following asymptotic
1514 # expansions:
1515 # ln(gamma(a)) ~ (a - 0.5) * ln(a) - a + 0.5 * ln(2 * pi) +
1516 # 1/(12 * a) - 1/(360 * a**3)
1517 # psi(a) ~ ln(a) - 1/(2 * a) - 1/(3 * a**2) + 1/120 * a**4)
1518 c = np.log(2) + 0.5*(1 + np.log(2*np.pi))
1519 h = 0.5/half_df
1520 return (h*(-2/3 + h*(-1/3 + h*(-4/45 + h/7.5))) +
1521 0.5*np.log(half_df) + c)
1522
1523 return _lazywhere(half_df < 125, (half_df, ),
1524 regular_formula,
1525 f2=asymptotic_formula)
1526
1527
1528chi2 = chi2_gen(a=0.0, name='chi2')
1529
1530
1531class cosine_gen(rv_continuous):
1532 r"""A cosine continuous random variable.
1533
1534 %(before_notes)s
1535
1536 Notes
1537 -----
1538 The cosine distribution is an approximation to the normal distribution.
1539 The probability density function for `cosine` is:
1540
1541 .. math::
1542
1543 f(x) = \frac{1}{2\pi} (1+\cos(x))
1544
1545 for :math:`-\pi \le x \le \pi`.
1546
1547 %(after_notes)s
1548
1549 %(example)s
1550
1551 """
1552 def _shape_info(self):
1553 return []
1554
1555 def _pdf(self, x):
1556 # cosine.pdf(x) = 1/(2*pi) * (1+cos(x))
1557 return 1.0/2/np.pi*(1+np.cos(x))
1558
1559 def _logpdf(self, x):
1560 c = np.cos(x)
1561 return _lazywhere(c != -1, (c,),
1562 lambda c: np.log1p(c) - np.log(2*np.pi),
1563 fillvalue=-np.inf)
1564
1565 def _cdf(self, x):
1566 return scu._cosine_cdf(x)
1567
1568 def _sf(self, x):
1569 return scu._cosine_cdf(-x)
1570
1571 def _ppf(self, p):
1572 return scu._cosine_invcdf(p)
1573
1574 def _isf(self, p):
1575 return -scu._cosine_invcdf(p)
1576
1577 def _stats(self):
1578 return 0.0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0-2.0, 0.0, -6.0*(np.pi**4-90)/(5.0*(np.pi*np.pi-6)**2)
1579
1580 def _entropy(self):
1581 return np.log(4*np.pi)-1.0
1582
1583
1584cosine = cosine_gen(a=-np.pi, b=np.pi, name='cosine')
1585
1586
1587class dgamma_gen(rv_continuous):
1588 r"""A double gamma continuous random variable.
1589
1590 The double gamma distribution is also known as the reflected gamma
1591 distribution [1]_.
1592
1593 %(before_notes)s
1594
1595 Notes
1596 -----
1597 The probability density function for `dgamma` is:
1598
1599 .. math::
1600
1601 f(x, a) = \frac{1}{2\Gamma(a)} |x|^{a-1} \exp(-|x|)
1602
1603 for a real number :math:`x` and :math:`a > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the
1604 gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`).
1605
1606 `dgamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`.
1607
1608 %(after_notes)s
1609
1610 References
1611 ----------
1612 .. [1] Johnson, Kotz, and Balakrishnan, "Continuous Univariate
1613 Distributions, Volume 1", Second Edition, John Wiley and Sons
1614 (1994).
1615
1616 %(example)s
1617
1618 """
1619 def _shape_info(self):
1620 return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1621
1622 def _rvs(self, a, size=None, random_state=None):
1623 u = random_state.uniform(size=size)
1624 gm = gamma.rvs(a, size=size, random_state=random_state)
1625 return gm * np.where(u >= 0.5, 1, -1)
1626
1627 def _pdf(self, x, a):
1628 # dgamma.pdf(x, a) = 1 / (2*gamma(a)) * abs(x)**(a-1) * exp(-abs(x))
1629 ax = abs(x)
1630 return 1.0/(2*sc.gamma(a))*ax**(a-1.0) * np.exp(-ax)
1631
1632 def _logpdf(self, x, a):
1633 ax = abs(x)
1634 return sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, ax) - ax - np.log(2) - sc.gammaln(a)
1635
1636 def _cdf(self, x, a):
1637 return np.where(x > 0,
1638 0.5 + 0.5*sc.gammainc(a, x),
1639 0.5*sc.gammaincc(a, -x))
1640
1641 def _sf(self, x, a):
1642 return np.where(x > 0,
1643 0.5*sc.gammaincc(a, x),
1644 0.5 + 0.5*sc.gammainc(a, -x))
1645
1646 def _entropy(self, a):
1647 return stats.gamma._entropy(a) - np.log(0.5)
1648
1649 def _ppf(self, q, a):
1650 return np.where(q > 0.5,
1651 sc.gammaincinv(a, 2*q - 1),
1652 -sc.gammainccinv(a, 2*q))
1653
1654 def _isf(self, q, a):
1655 return np.where(q > 0.5,
1656 -sc.gammaincinv(a, 2*q - 1),
1657 sc.gammainccinv(a, 2*q))
1658
1659 def _stats(self, a):
1660 mu2 = a*(a+1.0)
1661 return 0.0, mu2, 0.0, (a+2.0)*(a+3.0)/mu2-3.0
1662
1663
1664dgamma = dgamma_gen(name='dgamma')
1665
1666
1667class dweibull_gen(rv_continuous):
1668 r"""A double Weibull continuous random variable.
1669
1670 %(before_notes)s
1671
1672 Notes
1673 -----
1674 The probability density function for `dweibull` is given by
1675
1676 .. math::
1677
1678 f(x, c) = c / 2 |x|^{c-1} \exp(-|x|^c)
1679
1680 for a real number :math:`x` and :math:`c > 0`.
1681
1682 `dweibull` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
1683
1684 %(after_notes)s
1685
1686 %(example)s
1687
1688 """
1689 def _shape_info(self):
1690 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1691
1692 def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
1693 u = random_state.uniform(size=size)
1694 w = weibull_min.rvs(c, size=size, random_state=random_state)
1695 return w * (np.where(u >= 0.5, 1, -1))
1696
1697 def _pdf(self, x, c):
1698 # dweibull.pdf(x, c) = c / 2 * abs(x)**(c-1) * exp(-abs(x)**c)
1699 ax = abs(x)
1700 Px = c / 2.0 * ax**(c-1.0) * np.exp(-ax**c)
1701 return Px
1702
1703 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
1704 ax = abs(x)
1705 return np.log(c) - np.log(2.0) + sc.xlogy(c - 1.0, ax) - ax**c
1706
1707 def _cdf(self, x, c):
1708 Cx1 = 0.5 * np.exp(-abs(x)**c)
1709 return np.where(x > 0, 1 - Cx1, Cx1)
1710
1711 def _ppf(self, q, c):
1712 fac = 2. * np.where(q <= 0.5, q, 1. - q)
1713 fac = np.power(-np.log(fac), 1.0 / c)
1714 return np.where(q > 0.5, fac, -fac)
1715
1716 def _sf(self, x, c):
1717 half_weibull_min_sf = 0.5 * stats.weibull_min._sf(np.abs(x), c)
1718 return np.where(x > 0, half_weibull_min_sf, 1 - half_weibull_min_sf)
1719
1720 def _isf(self, q, c):
1721 double_q = 2. * np.where(q <= 0.5, q, 1. - q)
1722 weibull_min_isf = stats.weibull_min._isf(double_q, c)
1723 return np.where(q > 0.5, -weibull_min_isf, weibull_min_isf)
1724
1725 def _munp(self, n, c):
1726 return (1 - (n % 2)) * sc.gamma(1.0 + 1.0 * n / c)
1727
1728 # since we know that all odd moments are zeros, return them at once.
1729 # returning Nones from _stats makes the public stats call _munp
1730 # so overall we're saving one or two gamma function evaluations here.
1731 def _stats(self, c):
1732 return 0, None, 0, None
1733
1734 def _entropy(self, c):
1735 h = stats.weibull_min._entropy(c) - np.log(0.5)
1736 return h
1737
1738
1739dweibull = dweibull_gen(name='dweibull')
1740
1741
1742class expon_gen(rv_continuous):
1743 r"""An exponential continuous random variable.
1744
1745 %(before_notes)s
1746
1747 Notes
1748 -----
1749 The probability density function for `expon` is:
1750
1751 .. math::
1752
1753 f(x) = \exp(-x)
1754
1755 for :math:`x \ge 0`.
1756
1757 %(after_notes)s
1758
1759 A common parameterization for `expon` is in terms of the rate parameter
1760 ``lambda``, such that ``pdf = lambda * exp(-lambda * x)``. This
1761 parameterization corresponds to using ``scale = 1 / lambda``.
1762
1763 The exponential distribution is a special case of the gamma
1764 distributions, with gamma shape parameter ``a = 1``.
1765
1766 %(example)s
1767
1768 """
1769 def _shape_info(self):
1770 return []
1771
1772 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
1773 return random_state.standard_exponential(size)
1774
1775 def _pdf(self, x):
1776 # expon.pdf(x) = exp(-x)
1777 return np.exp(-x)
1778
1779 def _logpdf(self, x):
1780 return -x
1781
1782 def _cdf(self, x):
1783 return -sc.expm1(-x)
1784
1785 def _ppf(self, q):
1786 return -sc.log1p(-q)
1787
1788 def _sf(self, x):
1789 return np.exp(-x)
1790
1791 def _logsf(self, x):
1792 return -x
1793
1794 def _isf(self, q):
1795 return -np.log(q)
1796
1797 def _stats(self):
1798 return 1.0, 1.0, 2.0, 6.0
1799
1800 def _entropy(self):
1801 return 1.0
1802
1803 @_call_super_mom
1804 @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
1805 When `method='MLE'`,
1806 this function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood
1807 estimation of the exponential distribution parameters, so the
1808 `optimizer`, `loc` and `scale` keyword arguments are
1809 ignored.\n\n""")
1810 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
1811 if len(args) > 0:
1812 raise TypeError("Too many arguments.")
1813
1814 floc = kwds.pop('floc', None)
1815 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None)
1816
1817 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds)
1818
1819 if floc is not None and fscale is not None:
1820 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
1821 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
1822 "optimize.")
1823
1824 data = np.asarray(data)
1825
1826 if not np.isfinite(data).all():
1827 raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
1828
1829 data_min = data.min()
1830
1831 if floc is None:
1832 # ML estimate of the location is the minimum of the data.
1833 loc = data_min
1834 else:
1835 loc = floc
1836 if data_min < loc:
1837 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
1838 raise FitDataError("expon", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
1839
1840 if fscale is None:
1841 # ML estimate of the scale is the shifted mean.
1842 scale = data.mean() - loc
1843 else:
1844 scale = fscale
1845
1846 # We expect the return values to be floating point, so ensure it
1847 # by explicitly converting to float.
1848 return float(loc), float(scale)
1849
1850
1851expon = expon_gen(a=0.0, name='expon')
1852
1853
1854class exponnorm_gen(rv_continuous):
1855 r"""An exponentially modified Normal continuous random variable.
1856
1857 Also known as the exponentially modified Gaussian distribution [1]_.
1858
1859 %(before_notes)s
1860
1861 Notes
1862 -----
1863 The probability density function for `exponnorm` is:
1864
1865 .. math::
1866
1867 f(x, K) = \frac{1}{2K} \exp\left(\frac{1}{2 K^2} - x / K \right)
1868 \text{erfc}\left(-\frac{x - 1/K}{\sqrt{2}}\right)
1869
1870 where :math:`x` is a real number and :math:`K > 0`.
1871
1872 It can be thought of as the sum of a standard normal random variable
1873 and an independent exponentially distributed random variable with rate
1874 ``1/K``.
1875
1876 %(after_notes)s
1877
1878 An alternative parameterization of this distribution (for example, in
1879 the Wikpedia article [1]_) involves three parameters, :math:`\mu`,
1880 :math:`\lambda` and :math:`\sigma`.
1881
1882 In the present parameterization this corresponds to having ``loc`` and
1883 ``scale`` equal to :math:`\mu` and :math:`\sigma`, respectively, and
1884 shape parameter :math:`K = 1/(\sigma\lambda)`.
1885
1886 .. versionadded:: 0.16.0
1887
1888 References
1889 ----------
1890 .. [1] Exponentially modified Gaussian distribution, Wikipedia,
1891 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentially_modified_Gaussian_distribution
1892
1893 %(example)s
1894
1895 """
1896 def _shape_info(self):
1897 return [_ShapeInfo("K", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
1898
1899 def _rvs(self, K, size=None, random_state=None):
1900 expval = random_state.standard_exponential(size) * K
1901 gval = random_state.standard_normal(size)
1902 return expval + gval
1903
1904 def _pdf(self, x, K):
1905 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, K))
1906
1907 def _logpdf(self, x, K):
1908 invK = 1.0 / K
1909 exparg = invK * (0.5 * invK - x)
1910 return exparg + _norm_logcdf(x - invK) - np.log(K)
1911
1912 def _cdf(self, x, K):
1913 invK = 1.0 / K
1914 expval = invK * (0.5 * invK - x)
1915 logprod = expval + _norm_logcdf(x - invK)
1916 return _norm_cdf(x) - np.exp(logprod)
1917
1918 def _sf(self, x, K):
1919 invK = 1.0 / K
1920 expval = invK * (0.5 * invK - x)
1921 logprod = expval + _norm_logcdf(x - invK)
1922 return _norm_cdf(-x) + np.exp(logprod)
1923
1924 def _stats(self, K):
1925 K2 = K * K
1926 opK2 = 1.0 + K2
1927 skw = 2 * K**3 * opK2**(-1.5)
1928 krt = 6.0 * K2 * K2 * opK2**(-2)
1929 return K, opK2, skw, krt
1930
1931
1932exponnorm = exponnorm_gen(name='exponnorm')
1933
1934
1935def _pow1pm1(x, y):
1936 """
1937 Compute (1 + x)**y - 1.
1938
1939 Uses expm1 and xlog1py to avoid loss of precision when
1940 (1 + x)**y is close to 1.
1941
1942 Note that the inverse of this function with respect to x is
1943 ``_pow1pm1(x, 1/y)``. That is, if
1944
1945 t = _pow1pm1(x, y)
1946
1947 then
1948
1949 x = _pow1pm1(t, 1/y)
1950 """
1951 return np.expm1(sc.xlog1py(y, x))
1952
1953
1954class exponweib_gen(rv_continuous):
1955 r"""An exponentiated Weibull continuous random variable.
1956
1957 %(before_notes)s
1958
1959 See Also
1960 --------
1961 weibull_min, numpy.random.Generator.weibull
1962
1963 Notes
1964 -----
1965 The probability density function for `exponweib` is:
1966
1967 .. math::
1968
1969 f(x, a, c) = a c [1-\exp(-x^c)]^{a-1} \exp(-x^c) x^{c-1}
1970
1971 and its cumulative distribution function is:
1972
1973 .. math::
1974
1975 F(x, a, c) = [1-\exp(-x^c)]^a
1976
1977 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`c > 0`.
1978
1979 `exponweib` takes :math:`a` and :math:`c` as shape parameters:
1980
1981 * :math:`a` is the exponentiation parameter,
1982 with the special case :math:`a=1` corresponding to the
1983 (non-exponentiated) Weibull distribution `weibull_min`.
1984 * :math:`c` is the shape parameter of the non-exponentiated Weibull law.
1985
1986 %(after_notes)s
1987
1988 References
1989 ----------
1990 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentiated_Weibull_distribution
1991
1992 %(example)s
1993
1994 """
1995 def _shape_info(self):
1996 ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1997 ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
1998 return [ia, ic]
1999
2000 def _pdf(self, x, a, c):
2001 # exponweib.pdf(x, a, c) =
2002 # a * c * (1-exp(-x**c))**(a-1) * exp(-x**c)*x**(c-1)
2003 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, c))
2004
2005 def _logpdf(self, x, a, c):
2006 negxc = -x**c
2007 exm1c = -sc.expm1(negxc)
2008 logp = (np.log(a) + np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, exm1c) +
2009 negxc + sc.xlogy(c - 1.0, x))
2010 return logp
2011
2012 def _cdf(self, x, a, c):
2013 exm1c = -sc.expm1(-x**c)
2014 return exm1c**a
2015
2016 def _ppf(self, q, a, c):
2017 return (-sc.log1p(-q**(1.0/a)))**np.asarray(1.0/c)
2018
2019 def _sf(self, x, a, c):
2020 return -_pow1pm1(-np.exp(-x**c), a)
2021
2022 def _isf(self, p, a, c):
2023 return (-np.log(-_pow1pm1(-p, 1/a)))**(1/c)
2024
2025
2026exponweib = exponweib_gen(a=0.0, name='exponweib')
2027
2028
2029class exponpow_gen(rv_continuous):
2030 r"""An exponential power continuous random variable.
2031
2032 %(before_notes)s
2033
2034 Notes
2035 -----
2036 The probability density function for `exponpow` is:
2037
2038 .. math::
2039
2040 f(x, b) = b x^{b-1} \exp(1 + x^b - \exp(x^b))
2041
2042 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`b > 0`. Note that this is a different
2043 distribution from the exponential power distribution that is also known
2044 under the names "generalized normal" or "generalized Gaussian".
2045
2046 `exponpow` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`.
2047
2048 %(after_notes)s
2049
2050 References
2051 ----------
2052 http://www.math.wm.edu/~leemis/chart/UDR/PDFs/Exponentialpower.pdf
2053
2054 %(example)s
2055
2056 """
2057 def _shape_info(self):
2058 return [_ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
2059
2060 def _pdf(self, x, b):
2061 # exponpow.pdf(x, b) = b * x**(b-1) * exp(1 + x**b - exp(x**b))
2062 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, b))
2063
2064 def _logpdf(self, x, b):
2065 xb = x**b
2066 f = 1 + np.log(b) + sc.xlogy(b - 1.0, x) + xb - np.exp(xb)
2067 return f
2068
2069 def _cdf(self, x, b):
2070 return -sc.expm1(-sc.expm1(x**b))
2071
2072 def _sf(self, x, b):
2073 return np.exp(-sc.expm1(x**b))
2074
2075 def _isf(self, x, b):
2076 return (sc.log1p(-np.log(x)))**(1./b)
2077
2078 def _ppf(self, q, b):
2079 return pow(sc.log1p(-sc.log1p(-q)), 1.0/b)
2080
2081
2082exponpow = exponpow_gen(a=0.0, name='exponpow')
2083
2084
2085class fatiguelife_gen(rv_continuous):
2086 r"""A fatigue-life (Birnbaum-Saunders) continuous random variable.
2087
2088 %(before_notes)s
2089
2090 Notes
2091 -----
2092 The probability density function for `fatiguelife` is:
2093
2094 .. math::
2095
2096 f(x, c) = \frac{x+1}{2c\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp(-\frac{(x-1)^2}{2x c^2})
2097
2098 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c > 0`.
2099
2100 `fatiguelife` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2101
2102 %(after_notes)s
2103
2104 References
2105 ----------
2106 .. [1] "Birnbaum-Saunders distribution",
2107 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birnbaum-Saunders_distribution
2108
2109 %(example)s
2110
2111 """
2112 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
2113
2114 def _shape_info(self):
2115 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
2116
2117 def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
2118 z = random_state.standard_normal(size)
2119 x = 0.5*c*z
2120 x2 = x*x
2121 t = 1.0 + 2*x2 + 2*x*np.sqrt(1 + x2)
2122 return t
2123
2124 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2125 # fatiguelife.pdf(x, c) =
2126 # (x+1) / (2*c*sqrt(2*pi*x**3)) * exp(-(x-1)**2/(2*x*c**2))
2127 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c))
2128
2129 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
2130 return (np.log(x+1) - (x-1)**2 / (2.0*x*c**2) - np.log(2*c) -
2131 0.5*(np.log(2*np.pi) + 3*np.log(x)))
2132
2133 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2134 return _norm_cdf(1.0 / c * (np.sqrt(x) - 1.0/np.sqrt(x)))
2135
2136 def _ppf(self, q, c):
2137 tmp = c * _norm_ppf(q)
2138 return 0.25 * (tmp + np.sqrt(tmp**2 + 4))**2
2139
2140 def _sf(self, x, c):
2141 return _norm_sf(1.0 / c * (np.sqrt(x) - 1.0/np.sqrt(x)))
2142
2143 def _isf(self, q, c):
2144 tmp = -c * _norm_ppf(q)
2145 return 0.25 * (tmp + np.sqrt(tmp**2 + 4))**2
2146
2147 def _stats(self, c):
2148 # NB: the formula for kurtosis in wikipedia seems to have an error:
2149 # it's 40, not 41. At least it disagrees with the one from Wolfram
2150 # Alpha. And the latter one, below, passes the tests, while the wiki
2151 # one doesn't So far I didn't have the guts to actually check the
2152 # coefficients from the expressions for the raw moments.
2153 c2 = c*c
2154 mu = c2 / 2.0 + 1.0
2155 den = 5.0 * c2 + 4.0
2156 mu2 = c2*den / 4.0
2157 g1 = 4 * c * (11*c2 + 6.0) / np.power(den, 1.5)
2158 g2 = 6 * c2 * (93*c2 + 40.0) / den**2.0
2159 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
2160
2161
2162fatiguelife = fatiguelife_gen(a=0.0, name='fatiguelife')
2163
2164
2165class foldcauchy_gen(rv_continuous):
2166 r"""A folded Cauchy continuous random variable.
2167
2168 %(before_notes)s
2169
2170 Notes
2171 -----
2172 The probability density function for `foldcauchy` is:
2173
2174 .. math::
2175
2176 f(x, c) = \frac{1}{\pi (1+(x-c)^2)} + \frac{1}{\pi (1+(x+c)^2)}
2177
2178 for :math:`x \ge 0` and :math:`c \ge 0`.
2179
2180 `foldcauchy` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2181
2182 %(example)s
2183
2184 """
2185 def _argcheck(self, c):
2186 return c >= 0
2187
2188 def _shape_info(self):
2189 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))]
2190
2191 def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
2192 return abs(cauchy.rvs(loc=c, size=size,
2193 random_state=random_state))
2194
2195 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2196 # foldcauchy.pdf(x, c) = 1/(pi*(1+(x-c)**2)) + 1/(pi*(1+(x+c)**2))
2197 return 1.0/np.pi*(1.0/(1+(x-c)**2) + 1.0/(1+(x+c)**2))
2198
2199 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2200 return 1.0/np.pi*(np.arctan(x-c) + np.arctan(x+c))
2201
2202 def _sf(self, x, c):
2203 # 1 - CDF(x, c) = 1 - (atan(x - c) + atan(x + c))/pi
2204 # = ((pi/2 - atan(x - c)) + (pi/2 - atan(x + c)))/pi
2205 # = (acot(x - c) + acot(x + c))/pi
2206 # = (atan2(1, x - c) + atan2(1, x + c))/pi
2207 return (np.arctan2(1, x - c) + np.arctan2(1, x + c))/np.pi
2208
2209 def _stats(self, c):
2210 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
2211
2212
2213foldcauchy = foldcauchy_gen(a=0.0, name='foldcauchy')
2214
2215
2216class f_gen(rv_continuous):
2217 r"""An F continuous random variable.
2218
2219 For the noncentral F distribution, see `ncf`.
2220
2221 %(before_notes)s
2222
2223 See Also
2224 --------
2225 ncf
2226
2227 Notes
2228 -----
2229 The probability density function for `f` is:
2230
2231 .. math::
2232
2233 f(x, df_1, df_2) = \frac{df_2^{df_2/2} df_1^{df_1/2} x^{df_1 / 2-1}}
2234 {(df_2+df_1 x)^{(df_1+df_2)/2}
2235 B(df_1/2, df_2/2)}
2236
2237 for :math:`x > 0` and parameters :math:`df_1, df_2 > 0` .
2238
2239 `f` takes ``dfn`` and ``dfd`` as shape parameters.
2240
2241 %(after_notes)s
2242
2243 %(example)s
2244
2245 """
2246 def _shape_info(self):
2247 idfn = _ShapeInfo("dfn", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
2248 idfd = _ShapeInfo("dfd", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
2249 return [idfn, idfd]
2250
2251 def _rvs(self, dfn, dfd, size=None, random_state=None):
2252 return random_state.f(dfn, dfd, size)
2253
2254 def _pdf(self, x, dfn, dfd):
2255 # df2**(df2/2) * df1**(df1/2) * x**(df1/2-1)
2256 # F.pdf(x, df1, df2) = --------------------------------------------
2257 # (df2+df1*x)**((df1+df2)/2) * B(df1/2, df2/2)
2258 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, dfn, dfd))
2259
2260 def _logpdf(self, x, dfn, dfd):
2261 n = 1.0 * dfn
2262 m = 1.0 * dfd
2263 lPx = (m/2 * np.log(m) + n/2 * np.log(n) + sc.xlogy(n/2 - 1, x)
2264 - (((n+m)/2) * np.log(m + n*x) + sc.betaln(n/2, m/2)))
2265 return lPx
2266
2267 def _cdf(self, x, dfn, dfd):
2268 return sc.fdtr(dfn, dfd, x)
2269
2270 def _sf(self, x, dfn, dfd):
2271 return sc.fdtrc(dfn, dfd, x)
2272
2273 def _ppf(self, q, dfn, dfd):
2274 return sc.fdtri(dfn, dfd, q)
2275
2276 def _stats(self, dfn, dfd):
2277 v1, v2 = 1. * dfn, 1. * dfd
2278 v2_2, v2_4, v2_6, v2_8 = v2 - 2., v2 - 4., v2 - 6., v2 - 8.
2279
2280 mu = _lazywhere(
2281 v2 > 2, (v2, v2_2),
2282 lambda v2, v2_2: v2 / v2_2,
2283 np.inf)
2284
2285 mu2 = _lazywhere(
2286 v2 > 4, (v1, v2, v2_2, v2_4),
2287 lambda v1, v2, v2_2, v2_4:
2288 2 * v2 * v2 * (v1 + v2_2) / (v1 * v2_2**2 * v2_4),
2289 np.inf)
2290
2291 g1 = _lazywhere(
2292 v2 > 6, (v1, v2_2, v2_4, v2_6),
2293 lambda v1, v2_2, v2_4, v2_6:
2294 (2 * v1 + v2_2) / v2_6 * np.sqrt(v2_4 / (v1 * (v1 + v2_2))),
2295 np.nan)
2296 g1 *= np.sqrt(8.)
2297
2298 g2 = _lazywhere(
2299 v2 > 8, (g1, v2_6, v2_8),
2300 lambda g1, v2_6, v2_8: (8 + g1 * g1 * v2_6) / v2_8,
2301 np.nan)
2302 g2 *= 3. / 2.
2303
2304 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
2305
2306 def _entropy(self, dfn, dfd):
2307 # the formula found in literature is incorrect. This one yields the
2308 # same result as numerical integration using the generic entropy
2309 # definition. This is also tested in tests/test_conntinous_basic
2310 half_dfn = 0.5 * dfn
2311 half_dfd = 0.5 * dfd
2312 half_sum = 0.5 * (dfn + dfd)
2313
2314 return (np.log(dfd) - np.log(dfn) + sc.betaln(half_dfn, half_dfd) +
2315 (1 - half_dfn) * sc.psi(half_dfn) - (1 + half_dfd) *
2316 sc.psi(half_dfd) + half_sum * sc.psi(half_sum))
2317
2318
2319f = f_gen(a=0.0, name='f')
2320
2321
2322
2327
2328
2329
2330class foldnorm_gen(rv_continuous):
2331 r"""A folded normal continuous random variable.
2332
2333 %(before_notes)s
2334
2335 Notes
2336 -----
2337 The probability density function for `foldnorm` is:
2338
2339 .. math::
2340
2341 f(x, c) = \sqrt{2/\pi} cosh(c x) \exp(-\frac{x^2+c^2}{2})
2342
2343 for :math:`x \ge 0` and :math:`c \ge 0`.
2344
2345 `foldnorm` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2346
2347 %(after_notes)s
2348
2349 %(example)s
2350
2351 """
2352 def _argcheck(self, c):
2353 return c >= 0
2354
2355 def _shape_info(self):
2356 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))]
2357
2358 def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
2359 return abs(random_state.standard_normal(size) + c)
2360
2361 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2362 # foldnormal.pdf(x, c) = sqrt(2/pi) * cosh(c*x) * exp(-(x**2+c**2)/2)
2363 return _norm_pdf(x + c) + _norm_pdf(x-c)
2364
2365 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2366 sqrt_two = np.sqrt(2)
2367 return 0.5 * (sc.erf((x - c)/sqrt_two) + sc.erf((x + c)/sqrt_two))
2368
2369 def _sf(self, x, c):
2370 return _norm_sf(x - c) + _norm_sf(x + c)
2371
2372 def _stats(self, c):
2373 # Regina C. Elandt, Technometrics 3, 551 (1961)
2374 # https://www.jstor.org/stable/1266561
2375 #
2376 c2 = c*c
2377 expfac = np.exp(-0.5*c2) / np.sqrt(2.*np.pi)
2378
2379 mu = 2.*expfac + c * sc.erf(c/np.sqrt(2))
2380 mu2 = c2 + 1 - mu*mu
2381
2382 g1 = 2. * (mu*mu*mu - c2*mu - expfac)
2383 g1 /= np.power(mu2, 1.5)
2384
2385 g2 = c2 * (c2 + 6.) + 3 + 8.*expfac*mu
2386 g2 += (2. * (c2 - 3.) - 3. * mu**2) * mu**2
2387 g2 = g2 / mu2**2.0 - 3.
2388
2389 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
2390
2391
2392foldnorm = foldnorm_gen(a=0.0, name='foldnorm')
2393
2394
2395class weibull_min_gen(rv_continuous):
2396 r"""Weibull minimum continuous random variable.
2397
2398 The Weibull Minimum Extreme Value distribution, from extreme value theory
2399 (Fisher-Gnedenko theorem), is also often simply called the Weibull
2400 distribution. It arises as the limiting distribution of the rescaled
2401 minimum of iid random variables.
2402
2403 %(before_notes)s
2404
2405 See Also
2406 --------
2407 weibull_max, numpy.random.Generator.weibull, exponweib
2408
2409 Notes
2410 -----
2411 The probability density function for `weibull_min` is:
2412
2413 .. math::
2414
2415 f(x, c) = c x^{c-1} \exp(-x^c)
2416
2417 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`c > 0`.
2418
2419 `weibull_min` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2420 (named :math:`k` in Wikipedia article and :math:`a` in
2421 ``numpy.random.weibull``). Special shape values are :math:`c=1` and
2422 :math:`c=2` where Weibull distribution reduces to the `expon` and
2423 `rayleigh` distributions respectively.
2424
2425 %(after_notes)s
2426
2427 References
2428 ----------
2429 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution
2430
2431 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher-Tippett-Gnedenko_theorem
2432
2433 %(example)s
2434
2435 """
2436 def _shape_info(self):
2437 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
2438
2439 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2440 # weibull_min.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(c-1) * exp(-x**c)
2441 return c*pow(x, c-1)*np.exp(-pow(x, c))
2442
2443 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
2444 return np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(c - 1, x) - pow(x, c)
2445
2446 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2447 return -sc.expm1(-pow(x, c))
2448
2449 def _ppf(self, q, c):
2450 return pow(-sc.log1p(-q), 1.0/c)
2451
2452 def _sf(self, x, c):
2453 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c))
2454
2455 def _logsf(self, x, c):
2456 return -pow(x, c)
2457
2458 def _isf(self, q, c):
2459 return (-np.log(q))**(1/c)
2460
2461 def _munp(self, n, c):
2462 return sc.gamma(1.0+n*1.0/c)
2463
2464 def _entropy(self, c):
2465 return -_EULER / c - np.log(c) + _EULER + 1
2466
2467 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
2468 If ``method='mm'``, parameters fixed by the user are respected, and the
2469 remaining parameters are used to match distribution and sample moments
2470 where possible. For example, if the user fixes the location with
2471 ``floc``, the parameters will only match the distribution skewness and
2472 variance to the sample skewness and variance; no attempt will be made
2473 to match the means or minimize a norm of the errors.
2474 \n\n""")
2475 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
2476
2477 if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
2478 if data.num_censored() == 0:
2479 data = data._uncensor()
2480 else:
2481 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
2482
2483 if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
2484 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
2485
2486 # this extracts fixed shape, location, and scale however they
2487 # are specified, and also leaves them in `kwds`
2488 data, fc, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
2489 args, kwds)
2490 method = kwds.get("method", "mle").lower()
2491
2492 # See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution#Moments for
2493 # moment formulas.
2494 def skew(c):
2495 gamma1 = sc.gamma(1+1/c)
2496 gamma2 = sc.gamma(1+2/c)
2497 gamma3 = sc.gamma(1+3/c)
2498 num = 2 * gamma1**3 - 3*gamma1*gamma2 + gamma3
2499 den = (gamma2 - gamma1**2)**(3/2)
2500 return num/den
2501
2502 # For c in [1e2, 3e4], population skewness appears to approach
2503 # asymptote near -1.139, but past c > 3e4, skewness begins to vary
2504 # wildly, and MoM won't provide a good guess. Get out early.
2505 s = stats.skew(data)
2506 max_c = 1e4
2507 s_min = skew(max_c)
2508 if s < s_min and method != "mm" and fc is None and not args:
2509 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
2510
2511 # If method is method of moments, we don't need the user's guesses.
2512 # Otherwise, extract the guesses from args and kwds.
2513 if method == "mm":
2514 c, loc, scale = None, None, None
2515 else:
2516 c = args[0] if len(args) else None
2517 loc = kwds.pop('loc', None)
2518 scale = kwds.pop('scale', None)
2519
2520 if fc is None and c is None: # not fixed and no guess: use MoM
2521 # Solve for c that matches sample distribution skewness to sample
2522 # skewness.
2523 # we start having numerical issues with `weibull_min` with
2524 # parameters outside this range - and not just in this method.
2525 # We could probably improve the situation by doing everything
2526 # in the log space, but that is for another time.
2527 c = root_scalar(lambda c: skew(c) - s, bracket=[0.02, max_c],
2528 method='bisect').root
2529 elif fc is not None: # fixed: use it
2530 c = fc
2531
2532 if fscale is None and scale is None:
2533 v = np.var(data)
2534 scale = np.sqrt(v / (sc.gamma(1+2/c) - sc.gamma(1+1/c)**2))
2535 elif fscale is not None:
2536 scale = fscale
2537
2538 if floc is None and loc is None:
2539 m = np.mean(data)
2540 loc = m - scale*sc.gamma(1 + 1/c)
2541 elif floc is not None:
2542 loc = floc
2543
2544 if method == 'mm':
2545 return c, loc, scale
2546 else:
2547 # At this point, parameter "guesses" may equal the fixed parameters
2548 # in kwds. No harm in passing them as guesses, too.
2549 return super().fit(data, c, loc=loc, scale=scale, **kwds)
2550
2551
2552weibull_min = weibull_min_gen(a=0.0, name='weibull_min')
2553
2554
2555class truncweibull_min_gen(rv_continuous):
2556 r"""A doubly truncated Weibull minimum continuous random variable.
2557
2558 %(before_notes)s
2559
2560 See Also
2561 --------
2562 weibull_min, truncexpon
2563
2564 Notes
2565 -----
2566 The probability density function for `truncweibull_min` is:
2567
2568 .. math::
2569
2570 f(x, a, b, c) = \frac{c x^{c-1} \exp(-x^c)}{\exp(-a^c) - \exp(-b^c)}
2571
2572 for :math:`a < x <= b`, :math:`0 \le a < b` and :math:`c > 0`.
2573
2574 `truncweibull_min` takes :math:`a`, :math:`b`, and :math:`c` as shape
2575 parameters.
2576
2577 Notice that the truncation values, :math:`a` and :math:`b`, are defined in
2578 standardized form:
2579
2580 .. math::
2581
2582 a = (u_l - loc)/scale
2583 b = (u_r - loc)/scale
2584
2585 where :math:`u_l` and :math:`u_r` are the specific left and right
2586 truncation values, respectively. In other words, the support of the
2587 distribution becomes :math:`(a*scale + loc) < x <= (b*scale + loc)` when
2588 :math:`loc` and/or :math:`scale` are provided.
2589
2590 %(after_notes)s
2591
2592 References
2593 ----------
2594
2595 .. [1] Rinne, H. "The Weibull Distribution: A Handbook". CRC Press (2009).
2596
2597 %(example)s
2598
2599 """
2600 def _argcheck(self, c, a, b):
2601 return (a >= 0.) & (b > a) & (c > 0.)
2602
2603 def _shape_info(self):
2604 ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
2605 ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))
2606 ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
2607 return [ic, ia, ib]
2608
2609 def _fitstart(self, data):
2610 # Arbitrary, but default a=b=c=1 is not valid
2611 return super()._fitstart(data, args=(1, 0, 1))
2612
2613 def _get_support(self, c, a, b):
2614 return a, b
2615
2616 def _pdf(self, x, c, a, b):
2617 denum = (np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2618 return (c * pow(x, c-1) * np.exp(-pow(x, c))) / denum
2619
2620 def _logpdf(self, x, c, a, b):
2621 logdenum = np.log(np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2622 return np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(c - 1, x) - pow(x, c) - logdenum
2623
2624 def _cdf(self, x, c, a, b):
2625 num = (np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(x, c)))
2626 denum = (np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2627 return num / denum
2628
2629 def _logcdf(self, x, c, a, b):
2630 lognum = np.log(np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(x, c)))
2631 logdenum = np.log(np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2632 return lognum - logdenum
2633
2634 def _sf(self, x, c, a, b):
2635 num = (np.exp(-pow(x, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2636 denum = (np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2637 return num / denum
2638
2639 def _logsf(self, x, c, a, b):
2640 lognum = np.log(np.exp(-pow(x, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2641 logdenum = np.log(np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2642 return lognum - logdenum
2643
2644 def _isf(self, q, c, a, b):
2645 return pow(
2646 -np.log((1 - q) * np.exp(-pow(b, c)) + q * np.exp(-pow(a, c))), 1/c
2647 )
2648
2649 def _ppf(self, q, c, a, b):
2650 return pow(
2651 -np.log((1 - q) * np.exp(-pow(a, c)) + q * np.exp(-pow(b, c))), 1/c
2652 )
2653
2654 def _munp(self, n, c, a, b):
2655 gamma_fun = sc.gamma(n/c + 1.) * (
2656 sc.gammainc(n/c + 1., pow(b, c)) - sc.gammainc(n/c + 1., pow(a, c))
2657 )
2658 denum = (np.exp(-pow(a, c)) - np.exp(-pow(b, c)))
2659 return gamma_fun / denum
2660
2661
2662truncweibull_min = truncweibull_min_gen(name='truncweibull_min')
2663
2664
2665class weibull_max_gen(rv_continuous):
2666 r"""Weibull maximum continuous random variable.
2667
2668 The Weibull Maximum Extreme Value distribution, from extreme value theory
2669 (Fisher-Gnedenko theorem), is the limiting distribution of rescaled
2670 maximum of iid random variables. This is the distribution of -X
2671 if X is from the `weibull_min` function.
2672
2673 %(before_notes)s
2674
2675 See Also
2676 --------
2677 weibull_min
2678
2679 Notes
2680 -----
2681 The probability density function for `weibull_max` is:
2682
2683 .. math::
2684
2685 f(x, c) = c (-x)^{c-1} \exp(-(-x)^c)
2686
2687 for :math:`x < 0`, :math:`c > 0`.
2688
2689 `weibull_max` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2690
2691 %(after_notes)s
2692
2693 References
2694 ----------
2695 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution
2696
2697 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher-Tippett-Gnedenko_theorem
2698
2699 %(example)s
2700
2701 """
2702 def _shape_info(self):
2703 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
2704
2705 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2706 # weibull_max.pdf(x, c) = c * (-x)**(c-1) * exp(-(-x)**c)
2707 return c*pow(-x, c-1)*np.exp(-pow(-x, c))
2708
2709 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
2710 return np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(c-1, -x) - pow(-x, c)
2711
2712 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2713 return np.exp(-pow(-x, c))
2714
2715 def _logcdf(self, x, c):
2716 return -pow(-x, c)
2717
2718 def _sf(self, x, c):
2719 return -sc.expm1(-pow(-x, c))
2720
2721 def _ppf(self, q, c):
2722 return -pow(-np.log(q), 1.0/c)
2723
2724 def _munp(self, n, c):
2725 val = sc.gamma(1.0+n*1.0/c)
2726 if int(n) % 2:
2727 sgn = -1
2728 else:
2729 sgn = 1
2730 return sgn * val
2731
2732 def _entropy(self, c):
2733 return -_EULER / c - np.log(c) + _EULER + 1
2734
2735
2736weibull_max = weibull_max_gen(b=0.0, name='weibull_max')
2737
2738
2739class genlogistic_gen(rv_continuous):
2740 r"""A generalized logistic continuous random variable.
2741
2742 %(before_notes)s
2743
2744 Notes
2745 -----
2746 The probability density function for `genlogistic` is:
2747
2748 .. math::
2749
2750 f(x, c) = c \frac{\exp(-x)}
2751 {(1 + \exp(-x))^{c+1}}
2752
2753 for real :math:`x` and :math:`c > 0`.
2754
2755 `genlogistic` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2756
2757 %(after_notes)s
2758
2759 %(example)s
2760
2761 """
2762 def _shape_info(self):
2763 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
2764
2765 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2766 # genlogistic.pdf(x, c) = c * exp(-x) / (1 + exp(-x))**(c+1)
2767 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c))
2768
2769 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
2770 # Two mathematically equivalent expressions for log(pdf(x, c)):
2771 # log(pdf(x, c)) = log(c) - x - (c + 1)*log(1 + exp(-x))
2772 # = log(c) + c*x - (c + 1)*log(1 + exp(x))
2773 mult = -(c - 1) * (x < 0) - 1
2774 absx = np.abs(x)
2775 return np.log(c) + mult*absx - (c+1) * sc.log1p(np.exp(-absx))
2776
2777 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2778 Cx = (1+np.exp(-x))**(-c)
2779 return Cx
2780
2781 def _logcdf(self, x, c):
2782 return -c * np.log1p(np.exp(-x))
2783
2784 def _ppf(self, q, c):
2785 return -np.log(sc.powm1(q, -1.0/c))
2786
2787 def _sf(self, x, c):
2788 return -sc.expm1(self._logcdf(x, c))
2789
2790 def _isf(self, q, c):
2791 return self._ppf(1 - q, c)
2792
2793 def _stats(self, c):
2794 mu = _EULER + sc.psi(c)
2795 mu2 = np.pi*np.pi/6.0 + sc.zeta(2, c)
2796 g1 = -2*sc.zeta(3, c) + 2*_ZETA3
2797 g1 /= np.power(mu2, 1.5)
2798 g2 = np.pi**4/15.0 + 6*sc.zeta(4, c)
2799 g2 /= mu2**2.0
2800 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
2801
2802 def _entropy(self, c):
2803 return _lazywhere(c < 8e6, (c, ),
2804 lambda c: -np.log(c) + sc.psi(c + 1) + _EULER + 1,
2805 # asymptotic expansion: psi(c) ~ log(c) - 1/(2 * c)
2806 # a = -log(c) + psi(c + 1)
2807 # = -log(c) + psi(c) + 1/c
2808 # ~ -log(c) + log(c) - 1/(2 * c) + 1/c
2809 # = 1/(2 * c)
2810 f2=lambda c: 1/(2 * c) + _EULER + 1)
2811
2812
2813genlogistic = genlogistic_gen(name='genlogistic')
2814
2815
2816class genpareto_gen(rv_continuous):
2817 r"""A generalized Pareto continuous random variable.
2818
2819 %(before_notes)s
2820
2821 Notes
2822 -----
2823 The probability density function for `genpareto` is:
2824
2825 .. math::
2826
2827 f(x, c) = (1 + c x)^{-1 - 1/c}
2828
2829 defined for :math:`x \ge 0` if :math:`c \ge 0`, and for
2830 :math:`0 \le x \le -1/c` if :math:`c < 0`.
2831
2832 `genpareto` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
2833
2834 For :math:`c=0`, `genpareto` reduces to the exponential
2835 distribution, `expon`:
2836
2837 .. math::
2838
2839 f(x, 0) = \exp(-x)
2840
2841 For :math:`c=-1`, `genpareto` is uniform on ``[0, 1]``:
2842
2843 .. math::
2844
2845 f(x, -1) = 1
2846
2847 %(after_notes)s
2848
2849 %(example)s
2850
2851 """
2852 def _argcheck(self, c):
2853 return np.isfinite(c)
2854
2855 def _shape_info(self):
2856 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))]
2857
2858 def _get_support(self, c):
2859 c = np.asarray(c)
2860 b = _lazywhere(c < 0, (c,),
2861 lambda c: -1. / c,
2862 np.inf)
2863 a = np.where(c >= 0, self.a, self.a)
2864 return a, b
2865
2866 def _pdf(self, x, c):
2867 # genpareto.pdf(x, c) = (1 + c * x)**(-1 - 1/c)
2868 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c))
2869
2870 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
2871 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c),
2872 lambda x, c: -sc.xlog1py(c + 1., c*x) / c,
2873 -x)
2874
2875 def _cdf(self, x, c):
2876 return -sc.inv_boxcox1p(-x, -c)
2877
2878 def _sf(self, x, c):
2879 return sc.inv_boxcox(-x, -c)
2880
2881 def _logsf(self, x, c):
2882 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c),
2883 lambda x, c: -sc.log1p(c*x) / c,
2884 -x)
2885
2886 def _ppf(self, q, c):
2887 return -sc.boxcox1p(-q, -c)
2888
2889 def _isf(self, q, c):
2890 return -sc.boxcox(q, -c)
2891
2892 def _stats(self, c, moments='mv'):
2893 if 'm' not in moments:
2894 m = None
2895 else:
2896 m = _lazywhere(c < 1, (c,),
2897 lambda xi: 1/(1 - xi),
2898 np.inf)
2899 if 'v' not in moments:
2900 v = None
2901 else:
2902 v = _lazywhere(c < 1/2, (c,),
2903 lambda xi: 1 / (1 - xi)**2 / (1 - 2*xi),
2904 np.nan)
2905 if 's' not in moments:
2906 s = None
2907 else:
2908 s = _lazywhere(c < 1/3, (c,),
2909 lambda xi: (2 * (1 + xi) * np.sqrt(1 - 2*xi) /
2910 (1 - 3*xi)),
2911 np.nan)
2912 if 'k' not in moments:
2913 k = None
2914 else:
2915 k = _lazywhere(c < 1/4, (c,),
2916 lambda xi: (3 * (1 - 2*xi) * (2*xi**2 + xi + 3) /
2917 (1 - 3*xi) / (1 - 4*xi) - 3),
2918 np.nan)
2919 return m, v, s, k
2920
2921 def _munp(self, n, c):
2922 def __munp(n, c):
2923 val = 0.0
2924 k = np.arange(0, n + 1)
2925 for ki, cnk in zip(k, sc.comb(n, k)):
2926 val = val + cnk * (-1) ** ki / (1.0 - c * ki)
2927 return np.where(c * n < 1, val * (-1.0 / c) ** n, np.inf)
2928 return _lazywhere(c != 0, (c,),
2929 lambda c: __munp(n, c),
