5574 >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')
5575
5576 Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``:
5577
5578 >>> vals = levy.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999])
5579 >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy.cdf(vals))
5580 True
5581
5582 Generate random numbers:
5583
5584 >>> r = levy.rvs(size=1000)
5585
5586 And compare the histogram:
5587
5588 >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail
5589 >>> bins = np.concatenate((np.linspace(a, b, 20), [np.max(r)]))
5590 >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
5591 >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
5592 >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
5593 >>> plt.show()
5594
5595 """
5596 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5597
5598 def _shape_info(self):
5599 return []
5600
5601 def _pdf(self, x):
5602 # levy.pdf(x) = 1 / (x * sqrt(2*pi*x)) * exp(-1/(2*x))
5603 return 1 / np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x) / x * np.exp(-1/(2*x))
5604
5605 def _cdf(self, x):
5606 # Equivalent to 2*norm.sf(np.sqrt(1/x))
5607 return sc.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
5608
5609 def _sf(self, x):
5610 return sc.erf(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
5611
5612 def _ppf(self, q):
5613 # Equivalent to 1.0/(norm.isf(q/2)**2) or 0.5/(erfcinv(q)**2)
5614 val = _norm_isf(q/2)
5615 return 1.0 / (val * val)
5616
5617 def _isf(self, p):
5618 return 1/(2*sc.erfinv(p)**2)
5619
5620 def _stats(self):
5621 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
5622
5623
5624levy = levy_gen(a=0.0, name="levy")
5625
5626
5627class levy_l_gen(rv_continuous):
5628 r"""A left-skewed Levy continuous random variable.
5629
5630 %(before_notes)s
5631
5632 See Also
5633 --------
5634 levy, levy_stable
5635
5636 Notes
5637 -----
5638 The probability density function for `levy_l` is:
5639
5640 .. math::
5641 f(x) = \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{2\pi |x|}} \exp{ \left(-\frac{1}{2|x|} \right)}
5642
5643 for :math:`x < 0`.
5644
5645 This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and
5646 :math:`b=-1`.
5647
5648 %(after_notes)s
5649
5650 Examples
5651 --------
5652 >>> import numpy as np
5653 >>> from scipy.stats import levy_l
5654 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
5655 >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)
5656
5657 Calculate the first four moments:
5658
5659 >>> mean, var, skew, kurt = levy_l.stats(moments='mvsk')
5660
5661 Display the probability density function (``pdf``):
5662
5663 >>> # `levy_l` is very heavy-tailed.
5664 >>> # To show a nice plot, let's cut off the lower 40 percent.
5665 >>> a, b = levy_l.ppf(0.4), levy_l.ppf(1)
5666 >>> x = np.linspace(a, b, 100)
5667 >>> ax.plot(x, levy_l.pdf(x),
5668 ... 'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='levy_l pdf')
5669
5670 Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function)
5671 to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen"
5672 RV object holding the given parameters fixed.
5673
5674 Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``:
5675
5676 >>> rv = levy_l()
5677 >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')
5678
5679 Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``:
5680
5681 >>> vals = levy_l.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999])
5682 >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy_l.cdf(vals))
5683 True
5684
5685 Generate random numbers:
5686
5687 >>> r = levy_l.rvs(size=1000)
5688
5689 And compare the histogram:
5690
5691 >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail
5692 >>> bins = np.concatenate(([np.min(r)], np.linspace(a, b, 20)))
5693 >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
5694 >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
5695 >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
5696 >>> plt.show()
5697
5698 """
5699 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5700
5701 def _shape_info(self):
5702 return []
5703
5704 def _pdf(self, x):
5705 # levy_l.pdf(x) = 1 / (abs(x) * sqrt(2*pi*abs(x))) * exp(-1/(2*abs(x)))
5706 ax = abs(x)
5707 return 1/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*ax)/ax*np.exp(-1/(2*ax))
5708
5709 def _cdf(self, x):
5710 ax = abs(x)
5711 return 2 * _norm_cdf(1 / np.sqrt(ax)) - 1
5712
5713 def _sf(self, x):
5714 ax = abs(x)
5715 return 2 * _norm_sf(1 / np.sqrt(ax))
5716
5717 def _ppf(self, q):
5718 val = _norm_ppf((q + 1.0) / 2)
5719 return -1.0 / (val * val)
5720
5721 def _isf(self, p):
5722 return -1/_norm_isf(p/2)**2
5723
5724 def _stats(self):
5725 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
5726
5727
5728levy_l = levy_l_gen(b=0.0, name="levy_l")
5729
5730
5731class logistic_gen(rv_continuous):
5732 r"""A logistic (or Sech-squared) continuous random variable.
5733
5734 %(before_notes)s
5735
5736 Notes
5737 -----
5738 The probability density function for `logistic` is:
5739
5740 .. math::
5741
5742 f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x)}
5743 {(1+\exp(-x))^2}
5744
5745 `logistic` is a special case of `genlogistic` with ``c=1``.
5746
5747 Remark that the survival function (``logistic.sf``) is equal to the
5748 Fermi-Dirac distribution describing fermionic statistics.
5749
5750 %(after_notes)s
5751
5752 %(example)s
5753
5754 """
5755 def _shape_info(self):
5756 return []
5757
5758 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
5759 return random_state.logistic(size=size)
5760
5761 def _pdf(self, x):
5762 # logistic.pdf(x) = exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2
5763 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
5764
5765 def _logpdf(self, x):
5766 y = -np.abs(x)
5767 return y - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(y))
5768
5769 def _cdf(self, x):
5770 return sc.expit(x)
5771
5772 def _logcdf(self, x):
5773 return sc.log_expit(x)
5774
5775 def _ppf(self, q):
5776 return sc.logit(q)
5777
5778 def _sf(self, x):
5779 return sc.expit(-x)
5780
5781 def _logsf(self, x):
5782 return sc.log_expit(-x)
5783
5784 def _isf(self, q):
5785 return -sc.logit(q)
5786
5787 def _stats(self):
5788 return 0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0, 0, 6.0/5.0
5789
5790 def _entropy(self):
5791 # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution
5792 return 2.0
5793
5794 @_call_super_mom
5795 @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
5796 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
5797 if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
5798 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
5799
5800 data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
5801 args, kwds)
5802 n = len(data)
5803
5804 # rv_continuous provided guesses
5805 loc, scale = self._fitstart(data)
5806 # these are trumped by user-provided guesses
5807 loc, scale = kwds.get('loc', loc), kwds.get('scale', scale)
5808
5809 # the maximum likelihood estimators `a` and `b` of the location and
5810 # scale parameters are roots of the two equations described in `func`.
5811 # Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings, and
5812 # Peacock (2000), Page 130
5813
5814 def dl_dloc(loc, scale=fscale):
5815 c = (data - loc) / scale
5816 return np.sum(sc.expit(c)) - n/2
5817
5818 def dl_dscale(scale, loc=floc):
5819 c = (data - loc) / scale
5820 return np.sum(c*np.tanh(c/2)) - n
5821
5822 def func(params):
5823 loc, scale = params
5824 return dl_dloc(loc, scale), dl_dscale(scale, loc)
5825
5826 if fscale is not None and floc is None:
5827 res = optimize.root(dl_dloc, (loc,))
5828 loc = res.x[0]
5829 scale = fscale
5830 elif floc is not None and fscale is None:
5831 res = optimize.root(dl_dscale, (scale,))
5832 scale = res.x[0]
5833 loc = floc
5834 else:
5835 res = optimize.root(func, (loc, scale))
5836 loc, scale = res.x
5837
5838 # Note: gh-18176 reported data for which the reported MLE had
5839 # `scale < 0`. To fix the bug, we return abs(scale). This is OK because
5840 # `dl_dscale` and `dl_dloc` are even and odd functions of `scale`,
5841 # respectively, so if `-scale` is a solution, so is `scale`.
5842 scale = abs(scale)
5843 return ((loc, scale) if res.success
5844 else super().fit(data, *args, **kwds))
5845
5846
5847logistic = logistic_gen(name='logistic')
5848
5849
5850class loggamma_gen(rv_continuous):
5851 r"""A log gamma continuous random variable.
5852
5853 %(before_notes)s
5854
5855 Notes
5856 -----
5857 The probability density function for `loggamma` is:
5858
5859 .. math::
5860
5861 f(x, c) = \frac{\exp(c x - \exp(x))}
5862 {\Gamma(c)}
5863
5864 for all :math:`x, c > 0`. Here, :math:`\Gamma` is the
5865 gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`).
5866
5867 `loggamma` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
5868
5869 %(after_notes)s
5870
5871 %(example)s
5872
5873 """
5874
5875 def _shape_info(self):
5876 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5877
5878 def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
5879 # Use the property of the gamma distribution Gamma(c)
5880 # Gamma(c) ~ Gamma(c + 1)*U**(1/c),
5881 # where U is uniform on [0, 1]. (See, e.g.,
5882 # G. Marsaglia and W.W. Tsang, "A simple method for generating gamma
5883 # variables", https://doi.org/10.1145/358407.358414)
5884 # So
5885 # log(Gamma(c)) ~ log(Gamma(c + 1)) + log(U)/c
5886 # Generating a sample with this formulation is a bit slower
5887 # than the more obvious log(Gamma(c)), but it avoids loss
5888 # of precision when c << 1.
5889 return (np.log(random_state.gamma(c + 1, size=size))
5890 + np.log(random_state.uniform(size=size))/c)
5891
5892 def _pdf(self, x, c):
5893 # loggamma.pdf(x, c) = exp(c*x-exp(x)) / gamma(c)
5894 return np.exp(c*x-np.exp(x)-sc.gammaln(c))
5895
5896 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
5897 return c*x - np.exp(x) - sc.gammaln(c)
5898
5899 def _cdf(self, x, c):
5900 # This function is gammainc(c, exp(x)), where gammainc(c, z) is
5901 # the regularized incomplete gamma function.
5902 # The first term in a series expansion of gamminc(c, z) is
5903 # z**c/Gamma(c+1); see 6.5.29 of Abramowitz & Stegun (and refer
5904 # back to 6.5.1, 6.5.2 and 6.5.4 for the relevant notation).
5905 # This can also be found in the wikipedia article
5906 # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_gamma_function.
5907 # Here we use that formula when x is sufficiently negative that
5908 # exp(x) will result in subnormal numbers and lose precision.
5909 # We evaluate the log of the expression first to allow the possible
5910 # cancellation of the terms in the division, and then exponentiate.
5911 # That is,
5912 # exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1) = exp(log(exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1)))
5913 # = exp(c*x - gammaln(c+1))
5914 return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
5915 lambda x, c: np.exp(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
5916 f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammainc(c, np.exp(x)))
5917
5918 def _ppf(self, q, c):
5919 # The expression used when g < _XMIN inverts the one term expansion
5920 # given in the comments of _cdf().
5921 g = sc.gammaincinv(c, q)
5922 return _lazywhere(g < _XMIN, (g, q, c),
5923 lambda g, q, c: (np.log(q) + sc.gammaln(c+1))/c,
5924 f2=lambda g, q, c: np.log(g))
5925
5926 def _sf(self, x, c):
5927 # See the comments for _cdf() for how x < _LOGXMIN is handled.
5928 return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
5929 lambda x, c: -np.expm1(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
5930 f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammaincc(c, np.exp(x)))
5931
5932 def _isf(self, q, c):
5933 # The expression used when g < _XMIN inverts the complement of
5934 # the one term expansion given in the comments of _cdf().
5935 g = sc.gammainccinv(c, q)
5936 return _lazywhere(g < _XMIN, (g, q, c),
5937 lambda g, q, c: (np.log1p(-q) + sc.gammaln(c+1))/c,
5938 f2=lambda g, q, c: np.log(g))
5939
5940 def _stats(self, c):
5941 # See, for example, "A Statistical Study of Log-Gamma Distribution", by
5942 # Ping Shing Chan (thesis, McMaster University, 1993).
5943 mean = sc.digamma(c)
5944 var = sc.polygamma(1, c)
5945 skewness = sc.polygamma(2, c) / np.power(var, 1.5)
5946 excess_kurtosis = sc.polygamma(3, c) / (var*var)
5947 return mean, var, skewness, excess_kurtosis
5948
5949
5950loggamma = loggamma_gen(name='loggamma')
5951
5952
5953class loglaplace_gen(rv_continuous):
5954 r"""A log-Laplace continuous random variable.
5955
5956 %(before_notes)s
5957
5958 Notes
5959 -----
5960 The probability density function for `loglaplace` is:
5961
5962 .. math::
5963
5964 f(x, c) = \begin{cases}\frac{c}{2} x^{ c-1} &\text{for } 0 < x < 1\\
5965 \frac{c}{2} x^{-c-1} &\text{for } x \ge 1
5966 \end{cases}
5967
5968 for :math:`c > 0`.
5969
5970 `loglaplace` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
5971
5972 %(after_notes)s
5973
5974 References
5975 ----------
5976 T.J. Kozubowski and K. Podgorski, "A log-Laplace growth rate model",
5977 The Mathematical Scientist, vol. 28, pp. 49-60, 2003.
5978
5979 %(example)s
5980
5981 """
5982 def _shape_info(self):
5983 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5984
5985 def _pdf(self, x, c):
5986 # loglaplace.pdf(x, c) = c / 2 * x**(c-1), for 0 < x < 1
5987 # = c / 2 * x**(-c-1), for x >= 1
5988 cd2 = c/2.0
5989 c = np.where(x < 1, c, -c)
5990 return cd2*x**(c-1)
5991
5992 def _cdf(self, x, c):
5993 return np.where(x < 1, 0.5*x**c, 1-0.5*x**(-c))
5994
5995 def _ppf(self, q, c):
5996 return np.where(q < 0.5, (2.0*q)**(1.0/c), (2*(1.0-q))**(-1.0/c))
5997
5998 def _munp(self, n, c):
5999 return c**2 / (c**2 - n**2)
6000
6001 def _entropy(self, c):
6002 return np.log(2.0/c) + 1.0
6003
6004
6005loglaplace = loglaplace_gen(a=0.0, name='loglaplace')
6006
6007
6008def _lognorm_logpdf(x, s):
6009 return _lazywhere(x != 0, (x, s),
6010 lambda x, s: -np.log(x)**2 / (2*s**2) - np.log(s*x*np.sqrt(2*np.pi)),
6011 -np.inf)
6012
6013
6014class lognorm_gen(rv_continuous):
6015 r"""A lognormal continuous random variable.
6016
6017 %(before_notes)s
6018
6019 Notes
6020 -----
6021 The probability density function for `lognorm` is:
6022
6023 .. math::
6024
6025 f(x, s) = \frac{1}{s x \sqrt{2\pi}}
6026 \exp\left(-\frac{\log^2(x)}{2s^2}\right)
6027
6028 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`s > 0`.
6029
6030 `lognorm` takes ``s`` as a shape parameter for :math:`s`.
6031
6032 %(after_notes)s
6033
6034 Suppose a normally distributed random variable ``X`` has mean ``mu`` and
6035 standard deviation ``sigma``. Then ``Y = exp(X)`` is lognormally
6036 distributed with ``s = sigma`` and ``scale = exp(mu)``.
6037
6038 %(example)s
6039
6040 """
6041 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6042
6043 def _shape_info(self):
6044 return [_ShapeInfo("s", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6045
6046 def _rvs(self, s, size=None, random_state=None):
6047 return np.exp(s * random_state.standard_normal(size))
6048
6049 def _pdf(self, x, s):
6050 # lognorm.pdf(x, s) = 1 / (s*x*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2*(log(x)/s)**2)
6051 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, s))
6052
6053 def _logpdf(self, x, s):
6054 return _lognorm_logpdf(x, s)
6055
6056 def _cdf(self, x, s):
6057 return _norm_cdf(np.log(x) / s)
6058
6059 def _logcdf(self, x, s):
6060 return _norm_logcdf(np.log(x) / s)
6061
6062 def _ppf(self, q, s):
6063 return np.exp(s * _norm_ppf(q))
6064
6065 def _sf(self, x, s):
6066 return _norm_sf(np.log(x) / s)
6067
6068 def _logsf(self, x, s):
6069 return _norm_logsf(np.log(x) / s)
6070
6071 def _stats(self, s):
6072 p = np.exp(s*s)
6073 mu = np.sqrt(p)
6074 mu2 = p*(p-1)
6075 g1 = np.sqrt(p-1)*(2+p)
6076 g2 = np.polyval([1, 2, 3, 0, -6.0], p)
6077 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
6078
6079 def _entropy(self, s):
6080 return 0.5 * (1 + np.log(2*np.pi) + 2 * np.log(s))
6081
6082 @_call_super_mom
6083 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
6084 When `method='MLE'` and
6085 the location parameter is fixed by using the `floc` argument,
6086 this function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood
6087 estimation of the log-normal shape and scale parameters, so the
6088 `optimizer`, `loc` and `scale` keyword arguments are ignored.
6089 If the location is free, a likelihood maximum is found by
6090 setting its partial derivative wrt to location to 0, and
6091 solving by substituting the analytical expressions of shape
6092 and scale (or provided parameters).
6093 See, e.g., equation 3.1 in
6094 A. Clifford Cohen & Betty Jones Whitten (1980)
6095 Estimation in the Three-Parameter Lognormal Distribution,
6096 Journal of the American Statistical Association, 75:370, 399-404
6097 https://doi.org/10.2307/2287466
6098 \n\n""")
6099 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
6100 if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
6101 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6102
6103 parameters = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data, args, kwds)
6104 data, fshape, floc, fscale = parameters
6105 data_min = np.min(data)
6106
6107 def get_shape_scale(loc):
6108 # Calculate maximum likelihood scale and shape with analytical
6109 # formulas unless provided by the user
6110 if fshape is None or fscale is None:
6111 lndata = np.log(data - loc)
6112 scale = fscale or np.exp(lndata.mean())
6113 shape = fshape or np.sqrt(np.mean((lndata - np.log(scale))**2))
6114 return shape, scale
6115
6116 def dL_dLoc(loc):
6117 # Derivative of (positive) LL w.r.t. loc
6118 shape, scale = get_shape_scale(loc)
6119 shifted = data - loc
6120 return np.sum((1 + np.log(shifted/scale)/shape**2)/shifted)
6121
6122 def ll(loc):
6123 # (Positive) log-likelihood
6124 shape, scale = get_shape_scale(loc)
6125 return -self.nnlf((shape, loc, scale), data)
6126
6127 if floc is None:
6128 # The location must be less than the minimum of the data.
6129 # Back off a bit to avoid numerical issues.
6130 spacing = np.spacing(data_min)
6131 rbrack = data_min - spacing
6132
6133 # Find the right end of the bracket by successive doubling of the
6134 # distance to data_min. We're interested in a maximum LL, so the
6135 # slope dL_dLoc_rbrack should be negative at the right end.
6136 # optimization for later: share shape, scale
6137 dL_dLoc_rbrack = dL_dLoc(rbrack)
6138 ll_rbrack = ll(rbrack)
6139 delta = 2 * spacing # 2 * (data_min - rbrack)
6140 while dL_dLoc_rbrack >= -1e-6:
6141 rbrack = data_min - delta
6142 dL_dLoc_rbrack = dL_dLoc(rbrack)
6143 delta *= 2
6144
6145 if not np.isfinite(rbrack) or not np.isfinite(dL_dLoc_rbrack):
6146 # If we never find a negative slope, either we missed it or the
6147 # slope is always positive. It's usually the latter,
6148 # which means
6149 # loc = data_min - spacing
6150 # But sometimes when shape and/or scale are fixed there are
6151 # other issues, so be cautious.
6152 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6153
6154 # Now find the left end of the bracket. Guess is `rbrack-1`
6155 # unless that is too small of a difference to resolve. Double
6156 # the size of the interval until the left end is found.
6157 lbrack = np.minimum(np.nextafter(rbrack, -np.inf), rbrack-1)
6158 dL_dLoc_lbrack = dL_dLoc(lbrack)
6159 delta = 2 * (rbrack - lbrack)
6160 while (np.isfinite(lbrack) and np.isfinite(dL_dLoc_lbrack)
6161 and np.sign(dL_dLoc_lbrack) == np.sign(dL_dLoc_rbrack)):
6162 lbrack = rbrack - delta
6163 dL_dLoc_lbrack = dL_dLoc(lbrack)
6164 delta *= 2
6165
6166 # I don't recall observing this, but just in case...
6167 if not np.isfinite(lbrack) or not np.isfinite(dL_dLoc_lbrack):
6168 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6169
6170 # If we have a valid bracket, find the root
6171 res = root_scalar(dL_dLoc, bracket=(lbrack, rbrack))
6172 if not res.converged:
6173 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6174
6175 # If the slope was positive near the minimum of the data,
6176 # the maximum LL could be there instead of at the root. Compare
6177 # the LL of the two points to decide.
6178 ll_root = ll(res.root)
6179 loc = res.root if ll_root > ll_rbrack else data_min-spacing
6180
6181 else:
6182 if floc >= data_min:
6183 raise FitDataError("lognorm", lower=0., upper=np.inf)
6184 loc = floc
6185
6186 shape, scale = get_shape_scale(loc)
6187 if not (self._argcheck(shape) and scale > 0):
6188 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6189 return shape, loc, scale
6190
6191
6192lognorm = lognorm_gen(a=0.0, name='lognorm')
6193
6194
6195class gibrat_gen(rv_continuous):
6196 r"""A Gibrat continuous random variable.
6197
6198 %(before_notes)s
6199
6200 Notes
6201 -----
6202 The probability density function for `gibrat` is:
6203
6204 .. math::
6205
6206 f(x) = \frac{1}{x \sqrt{2\pi}} \exp(-\frac{1}{2} (\log(x))^2)
6207
6208 `gibrat` is a special case of `lognorm` with ``s=1``.
6209
6210 %(after_notes)s
6211
6212 %(example)s
6213
6214 """
6215 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6216
6217 def _shape_info(self):
6218 return []
6219
6220 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6221 return np.exp(random_state.standard_normal(size))
6222
6223 def _pdf(self, x):
6224 # gibrat.pdf(x) = 1/(x*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2*(log(x))**2)
6225 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
6226
6227 def _logpdf(self, x):
6228 return _lognorm_logpdf(x, 1.0)
6229
6230 def _cdf(self, x):
6231 return _norm_cdf(np.log(x))
6232
6233 def _ppf(self, q):
6234 return np.exp(_norm_ppf(q))
6235
6236 def _sf(self, x):
6237 return _norm_sf(np.log(x))
6238
6239 def _isf(self, p):
6240 return np.exp(_norm_isf(p))
6241
6242 def _stats(self):
6243 p = np.e
6244 mu = np.sqrt(p)
6245 mu2 = p * (p - 1)
6246 g1 = np.sqrt(p - 1) * (2 + p)
6247 g2 = np.polyval([1, 2, 3, 0, -6.0], p)
6248 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
6249
6250 def _entropy(self):
6251 return 0.5 * np.log(2 * np.pi) + 0.5
6252
6253
6254gibrat = gibrat_gen(a=0.0, name='gibrat')
6255
6256
6257class maxwell_gen(rv_continuous):
6258 r"""A Maxwell continuous random variable.
6259
6260 %(before_notes)s
6261
6262 Notes
6263 -----
6264 A special case of a `chi` distribution, with ``df=3``, ``loc=0.0``,
6265 and given ``scale = a``, where ``a`` is the parameter used in the
6266 Mathworld description [1]_.
6267
6268 The probability density function for `maxwell` is:
6269
6270 .. math::
6271
6272 f(x) = \sqrt{2/\pi}x^2 \exp(-x^2/2)
6273
6274 for :math:`x >= 0`.
6275
6276 %(after_notes)s
6277
6278 References
6279 ----------
6280 .. [1] http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MaxwellDistribution.html
6281
6282 %(example)s
6283 """
6284 def _shape_info(self):
6285 return []
6286
6287 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6288 return chi.rvs(3.0, size=size, random_state=random_state)
6289
6290 def _pdf(self, x):
6291 # maxwell.pdf(x) = sqrt(2/pi)x**2 * exp(-x**2/2)
6292 return _SQRT_2_OVER_PI*x*x*np.exp(-x*x/2.0)
6293
6294 def _logpdf(self, x):
6295 # Allow x=0 without 'divide by zero' warnings
6296 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
6297 return _LOG_SQRT_2_OVER_PI + 2*np.log(x) - 0.5*x*x
6298
6299 def _cdf(self, x):
6300 return sc.gammainc(1.5, x*x/2.0)
6301
6302 def _ppf(self, q):
6303 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammaincinv(1.5, q))
6304
6305 def _sf(self, x):
6306 return sc.gammaincc(1.5, x*x/2.0)
6307
6308 def _isf(self, q):
6309 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammainccinv(1.5, q))
6310
6311 def _stats(self):
6312 val = 3*np.pi-8
6313 return (2*np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi),
6314 3-8/np.pi,
6315 np.sqrt(2)*(32-10*np.pi)/val**1.5,
6316 (-12*np.pi*np.pi + 160*np.pi - 384) / val**2.0)
6317
6318 def _entropy(self):
6319 return _EULER + 0.5*np.log(2*np.pi)-0.5
6320
6321
6322maxwell = maxwell_gen(a=0.0, name='maxwell')
6323
6324
6325class mielke_gen(rv_continuous):
6326 r"""A Mielke Beta-Kappa / Dagum continuous random variable.
6327
6328 %(before_notes)s
6329
6330 Notes
6331 -----
6332 The probability density function for `mielke` is:
6333
6334 .. math::
6335
6336 f(x, k, s) = \frac{k x^{k-1}}{(1+x^s)^{1+k/s}}
6337
6338 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`k, s > 0`. The distribution is sometimes
6339 called Dagum distribution ([2]_). It was already defined in [3]_, called
6340 a Burr Type III distribution (`burr` with parameters ``c=s`` and
6341 ``d=k/s``).
6342
6343 `mielke` takes ``k`` and ``s`` as shape parameters.
6344
6345 %(after_notes)s
6346
6347 References
6348 ----------
6349 .. [1] Mielke, P.W., 1973 "Another Family of Distributions for Describing
6350 and Analyzing Precipitation Data." J. Appl. Meteor., 12, 275-280
6351 .. [2] Dagum, C., 1977 "A new model for personal income distribution."
6352 Economie Appliquee, 33, 327-367.
6353 .. [3] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of
6354 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942).
6355
6356 %(example)s
6357
6358 """
6359 def _shape_info(self):
6360 ik = _ShapeInfo("k", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
6361 i_s = _ShapeInfo("s", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
6362 return [ik, i_s]
6363
6364 def _pdf(self, x, k, s):
6365 return k*x**(k-1.0) / (1.0+x**s)**(1.0+k*1.0/s)
6366
6367 def _logpdf(self, x, k, s):
6368 # Allow x=0 without 'divide by zero' warnings.
6369 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
6370 return np.log(k) + np.log(x)*(k - 1) - np.log1p(x**s)*(1 + k/s)
6371
6372 def _cdf(self, x, k, s):
6373 return x**k / (1.0+x**s)**(k*1.0/s)
6374
6375 def _ppf(self, q, k, s):
6376 qsk = pow(q, s*1.0/k)
6377 return pow(qsk/(1.0-qsk), 1.0/s)
6378
6379 def _munp(self, n, k, s):
6380 def nth_moment(n, k, s):
6381 # n-th moment is defined for -k < n < s
6382 return sc.gamma((k+n)/s)*sc.gamma(1-n/s)/sc.gamma(k/s)
6383
6384 return _lazywhere(n < s, (n, k, s), nth_moment, np.inf)
6385
6386
6387mielke = mielke_gen(a=0.0, name='mielke')
6388
6389
6390class kappa4_gen(rv_continuous):
6391 r"""Kappa 4 parameter distribution.
6392
6393 %(before_notes)s
6394
6395 Notes
6396 -----
6397 The probability density function for kappa4 is:
6398
6399 .. math::
6400
6401 f(x, h, k) = (1 - k x)^{1/k - 1} (1 - h (1 - k x)^{1/k})^{1/h-1}
6402
6403 if :math:`h` and :math:`k` are not equal to 0.
6404
6405 If :math:`h` or :math:`k` are zero then the pdf can be simplified:
6406
6407 h = 0 and k != 0::
6408
6409 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*
6410 exp(-(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))
6411
6412 h != 0 and k = 0::
6413
6414 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = exp(-x)*(1.0 - h*exp(-x))**(1.0/h - 1.0)
6415
6416 h = 0 and k = 0::
6417
6418 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = exp(-x)*exp(-exp(-x))
6419
6420 kappa4 takes :math:`h` and :math:`k` as shape parameters.
6421
6422 The kappa4 distribution returns other distributions when certain
6423 :math:`h` and :math:`k` values are used.
6424
6425 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+
6426 | h | k=0.0 | k=1.0 | -inf<=k<=inf |
6427 +======+=============+================+==================+
6428 | -1.0 | Logistic | | Generalized |
6429 | | | | Logistic(1) |
6430 | | | | |
6431 | | logistic(x) | | |
6432 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+
6433 | 0.0 | Gumbel | Reverse | Generalized |
6434 | | | Exponential(2) | Extreme Value |
6435 | | | | |
6436 | | gumbel_r(x) | | genextreme(x, k) |
6437 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+
6438 | 1.0 | Exponential | Uniform | Generalized |
6439 | | | | Pareto |
6440 | | | | |
6441 | | expon(x) | uniform(x) | genpareto(x, -k) |
6442 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+
6443
6444 (1) There are at least five generalized logistic distributions.
6445 Four are described here:
6446 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_logistic_distribution
6447 The "fifth" one is the one kappa4 should match which currently
6448 isn't implemented in scipy:
6449 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Generalized_logistic_distribution
6450 https://www.mathwave.com/help/easyfit/html/analyses/distributions/gen_logistic.html
6451 (2) This distribution is currently not in scipy.
6452
6453 References
6454 ----------
6455 J.C. Finney, "Optimization of a Skewed Logistic Distribution With Respect
6456 to the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test", A Dissertation Submitted to the Graduate
6457 Faculty of the Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical
6458 College, (August, 2004),
6459 https://digitalcommons.lsu.edu/gradschool_dissertations/3672
6460
6461 J.R.M. Hosking, "The four-parameter kappa distribution". IBM J. Res.
6462 Develop. 38 (3), 25 1-258 (1994).
6463
6464 B. Kumphon, A. Kaew-Man, P. Seenoi, "A Rainfall Distribution for the Lampao
6465 Site in the Chi River Basin, Thailand", Journal of Water Resource and
6466 Protection, vol. 4, 866-869, (2012).
6467 :doi:`10.4236/jwarp.2012.410101`
6468
6469 C. Winchester, "On Estimation of the Four-Parameter Kappa Distribution", A
6470 Thesis Submitted to Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia, (March
6471 2000).
6472 http://www.nlc-bnc.ca/obj/s4/f2/dsk2/ftp01/MQ57336.pdf
6473
6474 %(after_notes)s
6475
6476 %(example)s
6477
6478 """
6479 def _argcheck(self, h, k):
6480 shape = np.broadcast_arrays(h, k)[0].shape
6481 return np.full(shape, fill_value=True)
6482
6483 def _shape_info(self):
6484 ih = _ShapeInfo("h", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
6485 ik = _ShapeInfo("k", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
6486 return [ih, ik]
6487
6488 def _get_support(self, h, k):
6489 condlist = [np.logical_and(h > 0, k > 0),
6490 np.logical_and(h > 0, k == 0),
6491 np.logical_and(h > 0, k < 0),
6492 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k > 0),
6493 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k == 0),
6494 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k < 0)]
6495
6496 def f0(h, k):
6497 return (1.0 - np.float_power(h, -k))/k
6498
6499 def f1(h, k):
6500 return np.log(h)
6501
6502 def f3(h, k):
6503 a = np.empty(np.shape(h))
6504 a[:] = -np.inf
6505 return a
6506
6507 def f5(h, k):
6508 return 1.0/k
6509
6510 _a = _lazyselect(condlist,
6511 [f0, f1, f0, f3, f3, f5],
6512 [h, k],
6513 default=np.nan)
6514
6515 def f0(h, k):
6516 return 1.0/k
6517
6518 def f1(h, k):
6519 a = np.empty(np.shape(h))
6520 a[:] = np.inf
6521 return a
6522
6523 _b = _lazyselect(condlist,
6524 [f0, f1, f1, f0, f1, f1],
6525 [h, k],
6526 default=np.nan)
6527 return _a, _b
6528
6529 def _pdf(self, x, h, k):
6530 # kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*
6531 # (1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h-1)
6532 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, h, k))
6533
6534 def _logpdf(self, x, h, k):
6535 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0),
6536 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0),
6537 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0),
6538 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)]
6539
6540 def f0(x, h, k):
6541 '''pdf = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*(
6542 1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h-1.0)
6543 logpdf = ...
6544 '''
6545 return (sc.xlog1py(1.0/k - 1.0, -k*x) +
6546 sc.xlog1py(1.0/h - 1.0, -h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)))
6547
6548 def f1(x, h, k):
6549 '''pdf = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*np.exp(-(
6550 1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))
6551 logpdf = ...
6552 '''
6553 return sc.xlog1py(1.0/k - 1.0, -k*x) - (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)
6554
6555 def f2(x, h, k):
6556 '''pdf = np.exp(-x)*(1.0 - h*np.exp(-x))**(1.0/h - 1.0)
6557 logpdf = ...
6558 '''
6559 return -x + sc.xlog1py(1.0/h - 1.0, -h*np.exp(-x))
6560
6561 def f3(x, h, k):
6562 '''pdf = np.exp(-x-np.exp(-x))
6563 logpdf = ...
6564 '''
6565 return -x - np.exp(-x)
6566
6567 return _lazyselect(condlist,
6568 [f0, f1, f2, f3],
6569 [x, h, k],
6570 default=np.nan)
6571
6572 def _cdf(self, x, h, k):
6573 return np.exp(self._logcdf(x, h, k))
6574
6575 def _logcdf(self, x, h, k):
6576 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0),
6577 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0),
6578 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0),
6579 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)]
6580
6581 def f0(x, h, k):
6582 '''cdf = (1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h)
6583 logcdf = ...
6584 '''
6585 return (1.0/h)*sc.log1p(-h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))
6586
6587 def f1(x, h, k):
6588 '''cdf = np.exp(-(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))
6589 logcdf = ...
6590 '''
6591 return -(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)
6592
6593 def f2(x, h, k):
6594 '''cdf = (1.0 - h*np.exp(-x))**(1.0/h)
6595 logcdf = ...
6596 '''
6597 return (1.0/h)*sc.log1p(-h*np.exp(-x))
6598
6599 def f3(x, h, k):
6600 '''cdf = np.exp(-np.exp(-x))
6601 logcdf = ...
6602 '''
6603 return -np.exp(-x)
6604
6605 return _lazyselect(condlist,
6606 [f0, f1, f2, f3],
6607 [x, h, k],
6608 default=np.nan)
6609
6610 def _ppf(self, q, h, k):
6611 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0),
6612 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0),
6613 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0),
6614 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)]
6615
6616 def f0(q, h, k):
6617 return 1.0/k*(1.0 - ((1.0 - (q**h))/h)**k)
6618
6619 def f1(q, h, k):
6620 return 1.0/k*(1.0 - (-np.log(q))**k)
6621
6622 def f2(q, h, k):
6623 '''ppf = -np.log((1.0 - (q**h))/h)
6624 '''
6625 return -sc.log1p(-(q**h)) + np.log(h)
6626
6627 def f3(q, h, k):
6628 return -np.log(-np.log(q))
6629
6630 return _lazyselect(condlist,
6631 [f0, f1, f2, f3],
6632 [q, h, k],
6633 default=np.nan)
6634
6635 def _get_stats_info(self, h, k):
6636 condlist = [
6637 np.logical_and(h < 0, k >= 0),
6638 k < 0,
6639 ]
6640
6641 def f0(h, k):
6642 return (-1.0/h*k).astype(int)
6643
6644 def f1(h, k):
6645 return (-1.0/k).astype(int)
6646
6647 return _lazyselect(condlist, [f0, f1], [h, k], default=5)
6648
6649 def _stats(self, h, k):
6650 maxr = self._get_stats_info(h, k)
6651 outputs = [None if np.any(r < maxr) else np.nan for r in range(1, 5)]
6652 return outputs[:]
6653
6654 def _mom1_sc(self, m, *args):
6655 maxr = self._get_stats_info(args[0], args[1])
6656 if m >= maxr:
6657 return np.nan
6658 return integrate.quad(self._mom_integ1, 0, 1, args=(m,)+args)[0]
6659
6660
6661kappa4 = kappa4_gen(name='kappa4')
6662
6663
6664class kappa3_gen(rv_continuous):
6665 r"""Kappa 3 parameter distribution.
6666
6667 %(before_notes)s
6668
6669 Notes
6670 -----
6671 The probability density function for `kappa3` is:
6672
6673 .. math::
6674
6675 f(x, a) = a (a + x^a)^{-(a + 1)/a}
6676
6677 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`a > 0`.
6678
6679 `kappa3` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`.
6680
6681 References
6682 ----------
6683 P.W. Mielke and E.S. Johnson, "Three-Parameter Kappa Distribution Maximum
6684 Likelihood and Likelihood Ratio Tests", Methods in Weather Research,
6685 701-707, (September, 1973),
6686 :doi:`10.1175/1520-0493(1973)101<0701:TKDMLE>2.3.CO;2`
6687
6688 B. Kumphon, "Maximum Entropy and Maximum Likelihood Estimation for the
6689 Three-Parameter Kappa Distribution", Open Journal of Statistics, vol 2,
6690 415-419 (2012), :doi:`10.4236/ojs.2012.24050`
6691
6692 %(after_notes)s
6693
6694 %(example)s
6695
6696 """
6697 def _shape_info(self):
6698 return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6699
6700 def _pdf(self, x, a):
6701 # kappa3.pdf(x, a) = a*(a + x**a)**(-(a + 1)/a), for x > 0
6702 return a*(a + x**a)**(-1.0/a-1)
6703
6704 def _cdf(self, x, a):
6705 return x*(a + x**a)**(-1.0/a)
6706
6707 def _ppf(self, q, a):
6708 return (a/(q**-a - 1.0))**(1.0/a)
6709
6710 def _stats(self, a):
6711 outputs = [None if np.any(i < a) else np.nan for i in range(1, 5)]
6712 return outputs[:]
6713
6714 def _mom1_sc(self, m, *args):
6715 if np.any(m >= args[0]):
6716 return np.nan
6717 return integrate.quad(self._mom_integ1, 0, 1, args=(m,)+args)[0]
6718
6719
6720kappa3 = kappa3_gen(a=0.0, name='kappa3')
6721
6722
6723class moyal_gen(rv_continuous):
6724 r"""A Moyal continuous random variable.
6725
6726 %(before_notes)s
6727
6728 Notes
6729 -----
6730 The probability density function for `moyal` is:
6731
6732 .. math::
6733
6734 f(x) = \exp(-(x + \exp(-x))/2) / \sqrt{2\pi}
6735
6736 for a real number :math:`x`.
6737
6738 %(after_notes)s
6739
6740 This distribution has utility in high-energy physics and radiation
6741 detection. It describes the energy loss of a charged relativistic
6742 particle due to ionization of the medium [1]_. It also provides an
6743 approximation for the Landau distribution. For an in depth description
6744 see [2]_. For additional description, see [3]_.
6745
6746 References
6747 ----------
6748 .. [1] J.E. Moyal, "XXX. Theory of ionization fluctuations",
6749 The London, Edinburgh, and Dublin Philosophical Magazine
6750 and Journal of Science, vol 46, 263-280, (1955).
6751 :doi:`10.1080/14786440308521076` (gated)
6752 .. [2] G. Cordeiro et al., "The beta Moyal: a useful skew distribution",
6753 International Journal of Research and Reviews in Applied Sciences,
6754 vol 10, 171-192, (2012).
6755 http://www.arpapress.com/Volumes/Vol10Issue2/IJRRAS_10_2_02.pdf
6756 .. [3] C. Walck, "Handbook on Statistical Distributions for
6757 Experimentalists; International Report SUF-PFY/96-01", Chapter 26,
6758 University of Stockholm: Stockholm, Sweden, (2007).
6759 http://www.stat.rice.edu/~dobelman/textfiles/DistributionsHandbook.pdf
6760
6761 .. versionadded:: 1.1.0
6762
6763 %(example)s
6764
6765 """
6766 def _shape_info(self):
6767 return []
6768
6769 def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6770 u1 = gamma.rvs(a=0.5, scale=2, size=size,
6771 random_state=random_state)
6772 return -np.log(u1)
6773
6774 def _pdf(self, x):
6775 return np.exp(-0.5 * (x + np.exp(-x))) / np.sqrt(2*np.pi)
6776
6777 def _cdf(self, x):
6778 return sc.erfc(np.exp(-0.5 * x) / np.sqrt(2))
6779
6780 def _sf(self, x):
6781 return sc.erf(np.exp(-0.5 * x) / np.sqrt(2))
6782
6783 def _ppf(self, x):
6784 return -np.log(2 * sc.erfcinv(x)**2)
6785
6786 def _stats(self):
6787 mu = np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma
6788 mu2 = np.pi**2 / 2
6789 g1 = 28 * np.sqrt(2) * sc.zeta(3) / np.pi**3
6790 g2 = 4.
6791 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
6792
6793 def _munp(self, n):
6794 if n == 1.0:
6795 return np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma
6796 elif n == 2.0:
6797 return np.pi**2 / 2 + (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**2
6798 elif n == 3.0:
6799 tmp1 = 1.5 * np.pi**2 * (np.log(2)+np.euler_gamma)
6800 tmp2 = (np.log(2)+np.euler_gamma)**3
6801 tmp3 = 14 * sc.zeta(3)
6802 return tmp1 + tmp2 + tmp3
6803 elif n == 4.0:
6804 tmp1 = 4 * 14 * sc.zeta(3) * (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)
6805 tmp2 = 3 * np.pi**2 * (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**2
6806 tmp3 = (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**4
6807 tmp4 = 7 * np.pi**4 / 4
6808 return tmp1 + tmp2 + tmp3 + tmp4
6809 else:
6810 # return generic for higher moments
6811 # return rv_continuous._mom1_sc(self, n, b)
6812 return self._mom1_sc(n)
6813
6814
6815moyal = moyal_gen(name="moyal")
6816
6817
6818class nakagami_gen(rv_continuous):
6819 r"""A Nakagami continuous random variable.
6820
6821 %(before_notes)s
6822
6823 Notes
6824 -----
6825 The probability density function for `nakagami` is:
6826
6827 .. math::
6828
6829 f(x, \nu) = \frac{2 \nu^\nu}{\Gamma(\nu)} x^{2\nu-1} \exp(-\nu x^2)
6830
6831 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`\nu > 0`. The distribution was introduced in
6832 [2]_, see also [1]_ for further information.
6833
6834 `nakagami` takes ``nu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\nu`.
6835
6836 %(after_notes)s
6837
6838 References
6839 ----------
6840 .. [1] "Nakagami distribution", Wikipedia
6841 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakagami_distribution
6842 .. [2] M. Nakagami, "The m-distribution - A general formula of intensity
6843 distribution of rapid fading", Statistical methods in radio wave
6844 propagation, Pergamon Press, 1960, 3-36.
6845 :doi:`10.1016/B978-0-08-009306-2.50005-4`
6846
6847 %(example)s
6848
6849 """
6850 def _argcheck(self, nu):
6851 return nu > 0
6852
6853 def _shape_info(self):
6854 return [_ShapeInfo("nu", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6855
6856 def _pdf(self, x, nu):
6857 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, nu))
6858
6859 def _logpdf(self, x, nu):
6860 # nakagami.pdf(x, nu) = 2 * nu**nu / gamma(nu) *
6861 # x**(2*nu-1) * exp(-nu*x**2)
6862 return (np.log(2) + sc.xlogy(nu, nu) - sc.gammaln(nu) +
6863 sc.xlogy(2*nu - 1, x) - nu*x**2)
6864
6865 def _cdf(self, x, nu):
6866 return sc.gammainc(nu, nu*x*x)
6867
6868 def _ppf(self, q, nu):
6869 return np.sqrt(1.0/nu*sc.gammaincinv(nu, q))
6870
6871 def _sf(self, x, nu):
6872 return sc.gammaincc(nu, nu*x*x)
6873
6874 def _isf(self, p, nu):
6875 return np.sqrt(1/nu * sc.gammainccinv(nu, p))
6876
6877 def _stats(self, nu):
6878 mu = sc.gamma(nu+0.5)/sc.gamma(nu)/np.sqrt(nu)
6879 mu2 = 1.0-mu*mu
6880 g1 = mu * (1 - 4*nu*mu2) / 2.0 / nu / np.power(mu2, 1.5)
6881 g2 = -6*mu**4*nu + (8*nu-2)*mu**2-2*nu + 1
6882 g2 /= nu*mu2**2.0
6883 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
6884
6885 def _entropy(self, nu):
6886 shape = np.shape(nu)
6887 # because somehow this isn't taken care of by the infrastructure...
6888 nu = np.atleast_1d(nu)
6889 A = sc.gammaln(nu)
6890 B = nu - (nu - 0.5) * sc.digamma(nu)
6891 C = -0.5 * np.log(nu) - np.log(2)
6892 h = A + B + C
6893 # This is the asymptotic sum of A and B (see gh-17868)
6894 norm_entropy = stats.norm._entropy()
6895 # Above, this is lost to rounding error for large nu, so use the
6896 # asymptotic sum when the approximation becomes accurate
6897 i = nu > 5e4 # roundoff error ~ approximation error
6898 # -1 / (12 * nu) is the O(1/nu) term; see gh-17929
6899 h[i] = C[i] + norm_entropy - 1/(12*nu[i])
6900 return h.reshape(shape)[()]
6901
6902 def _rvs(self, nu, size=None, random_state=None):
6903 # this relationship can be found in [1] or by a direct calculation
6904 return np.sqrt(random_state.standard_gamma(nu, size=size) / nu)
6905
6906 def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
6907 if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
6908 data = data._uncensor()
6909 if args is None:
6910 args = (1.0,) * self.numargs
6911 # Analytical justified estimates
6912 # see: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/tutorial/stats/continuous_nakagami.html
6913 loc = np.min(data)
6914 scale = np.sqrt(np.sum((data - loc)**2) / len(data))
6915 return args + (loc, scale)
6916
6917
6918nakagami = nakagami_gen(a=0.0, name="nakagami")
6919
6920
6921# The function name ncx2 is an abbreviation for noncentral chi squared.
6922def _ncx2_log_pdf(x, df, nc):
6923 # We use (xs**2 + ns**2)/2 = (xs - ns)**2/2 + xs*ns, and include the
6924 # factor of exp(-xs*ns) into the ive function to improve numerical
6925 # stability at large values of xs. See also `rice.pdf`.
6926 df2 = df/2.0 - 1.0
6927 xs, ns = np.sqrt(x), np.sqrt(nc)
6928 res = sc.xlogy(df2/2.0, x/nc) - 0.5*(xs - ns)**2
6929 corr = sc.ive(df2, xs*ns) / 2.0
6930 # Return res + np.log(corr) avoiding np.log(0)
6931 return _lazywhere(
6932 corr > 0,
6933 (res, corr),
6934 f=lambda r, c: r + np.log(c),
6935 fillvalue=-np.inf)
6936
6937
6938class ncx2_gen(rv_continuous):
6939 r"""A non-central chi-squared continuous random variable.
6940
6941 %(before_notes)s
6942
6943 Notes
6944 -----
6945 The probability density function for `ncx2` is:
6946
6947 .. math::
6948
6949 f(x, k, \lambda) = \frac{1}{2} \exp(-(\lambda+x)/2)
6950 (x/\lambda)^{(k-2)/4} I_{(k-2)/2}(\sqrt{\lambda x})
6951
6952 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`k > 0` and :math:`\lambda \ge 0`.
6953 :math:`k` specifies the degrees of freedom (denoted ``df`` in the
6954 implementation) and :math:`\lambda` is the non-centrality parameter
6955 (denoted ``nc`` in the implementation). :math:`I_\nu` denotes the
6956 modified Bessel function of first order of degree :math:`\nu`
6957 (`scipy.special.iv`).
6958
6959 `ncx2` takes ``df`` and ``nc`` as shape parameters.
6960
6961 %(after_notes)s
6962
6963 %(example)s
6964
6965 """
6966 def _argcheck(self, df, nc):
6967 return (df > 0) & np.isfinite(df) & (nc >= 0)
6968
6969 def _shape_info(self):
6970 idf = _ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
6971 inc = _ShapeInfo("nc", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))
6972 return [idf, inc]
6973
6974 def _rvs(self, df, nc, size=None, random_state=None):
6975 return random_state.noncentral_chisquare(df, nc, size)
6976
6977 def _logpdf(self, x, df, nc):
6978 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
6979 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_ncx2_log_pdf,
6980 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._logpdf(x, df))
6981
6982 def _pdf(self, x, df, nc):
6983 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
6984 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
6985 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_boost._ncx2_pdf,
6986 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._pdf(x, df))
6987
6988 def _cdf(self, x, df, nc):
6989 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
6990 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
6991 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_boost._ncx2_cdf,
6992 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._cdf(x, df))
6993
6994 def _ppf(self, q, df, nc):
6995 cond = np.ones_like(q, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
6996 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
6997 return _lazywhere(cond, (q, df, nc), f=_boost._ncx2_ppf,
6998 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._ppf(x, df))
6999
7000 def _sf(self, x, df, nc):
7001 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
7002 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7003 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_boost._ncx2_sf,
7004 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._sf(x, df))
7005
7006 def _isf(self, x, df, nc):
7007 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0)
7008 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7009 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_boost._ncx2_isf,
7010 f2=lambda x, df, _: chi2._isf(x, df))
7011
7012 def _stats(self, df, nc):
7013 return (
7014 _boost._ncx2_mean(df, nc),
7015 _boost._ncx2_variance(df, nc),
7016 _boost._ncx2_skewness(df, nc),
7017 _boost._ncx2_kurtosis_excess(df, nc),
7018 )
7019
7020
7021ncx2 = ncx2_gen(a=0.0, name='ncx2')
7022
7023
7024class ncf_gen(rv_continuous):
7025 r"""A non-central F distribution continuous random variable.
7026
7027 %(before_notes)s
7028
7029 See Also
7030 --------
7031 scipy.stats.f : Fisher distribution
7032
7033 Notes
7034 -----
7035 The probability density function for `ncf` is:
7036
7037 .. math::
7038
7039 f(x, n_1, n_2, \lambda) =
7040 \exp\left(\frac{\lambda}{2} +
7041 \lambda n_1 \frac{x}{2(n_1 x + n_2)}
7042 \right)
7043 n_1^{n_1/2} n_2^{n_2/2} x^{n_1/2 - 1} \\
7044 (n_2 + n_1 x)^{-(n_1 + n_2)/2}
7045 \gamma(n_1/2) \gamma(1 + n_2/2) \\
7046 \frac{L^{\frac{n_1}{2}-1}_{n_2/2}
7047 \left(-\lambda n_1 \frac{x}{2(n_1 x + n_2)}\right)}
7048 {B(n_1/2, n_2/2)
7049 \gamma\left(\frac{n_1 + n_2}{2}\right)}
7050
7051 for :math:`n_1, n_2 > 0`, :math:`\lambda \ge 0`. Here :math:`n_1` is the
7052 degrees of freedom in the numerator, :math:`n_2` the degrees of freedom in
7053 the denominator, :math:`\lambda` the non-centrality parameter,
7054 :math:`\gamma` is the logarithm of the Gamma function, :math:`L_n^k` is a
7055 generalized Laguerre polynomial and :math:`B` is the beta function.
7056
7057 `ncf` takes ``df1``, ``df2`` and ``nc`` as shape parameters. If ``nc=0``,
7058 the distribution becomes equivalent to the Fisher distribution.
7059
7060 %(after_notes)s
7061
7062 %(example)s
7063
7064 """
7065 def _argcheck(self, df1, df2, nc):
7066 return (df1 > 0) & (df2 > 0) & (nc >= 0)
7067
7068 def _shape_info(self):
7069 idf1 = _ShapeInfo("df1", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
7070 idf2 = _ShapeInfo("df2", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
7071 inc = _ShapeInfo("nc", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))
7072 return [idf1, idf2, inc]
7073
7074 def _rvs(self, dfn, dfd, nc, size=None, random_state=None):
7075 return random_state.noncentral_f(dfn, dfd, nc, size)
7076
7077 def _pdf(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc):
7078 # ncf.pdf(x, df1, df2, nc) = exp(nc/2 + nc*df1*x/(2*(df1*x+df2))) *
7079 # df1**(df1/2) * df2**(df2/2) * x**(df1/2-1) *
7080 # (df2+df1*x)**(-(df1+df2)/2) *
7081 # gamma(df1/2)*gamma(1+df2/2) *
7082 # L^{v1/2-1}^{v2/2}(-nc*v1*x/(2*(v1*x+v2))) /
7083 # (B(v1/2, v2/2) * gamma((v1+v2)/2))
7084 return _boost._ncf_pdf(x, dfn, dfd, nc)
7085
7086 def _cdf(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc):
7087 return _boost._ncf_cdf(x, dfn, dfd, nc)
7088
7089 def _ppf(self, q, dfn, dfd, nc):
7090 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7091 return _boost._ncf_ppf(q, dfn, dfd, nc)
7092
7093 def _sf(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc):
7094 return _boost._ncf_sf(x, dfn, dfd, nc)
7095
7096 def _isf(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc):
7097 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7098 return _boost._ncf_isf(x, dfn, dfd, nc)
7099
7100 def _munp(self, n, dfn, dfd, nc):
7101 val = (dfn * 1.0/dfd)**n
7102 term = sc.gammaln(n+0.5*dfn) + sc.gammaln(0.5*dfd-n) - sc.gammaln(dfd*0.5)
7103 val *= np.exp(-nc / 2.0+term)
7104 val *= sc.hyp1f1(n+0.5*dfn, 0.5*dfn, 0.5*nc)
7105 return val
7106
7107 def _stats(self, dfn, dfd, nc, moments='mv'):
7108 mu = _boost._ncf_mean(dfn, dfd, nc)
7109 mu2 = _boost._ncf_variance(dfn, dfd, nc)
7110 g1 = _boost._ncf_skewness(dfn, dfd, nc) if 's' in moments else None
7111 g2 = _boost._ncf_kurtosis_excess(
7112 dfn, dfd, nc) if 'k' in moments else None
7113 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
7114
7115
7116ncf = ncf_gen(a=0.0, name='ncf')
7117
7118
7119class t_gen(rv_continuous):
7120 r"""A Student's t continuous random variable.
7121
7122 For the noncentral t distribution, see `nct`.
7123
7124 %(before_notes)s
7125
7126 See Also
7127 --------
7128 nct
7129
7130 Notes
7131 -----
7132 The probability density function for `t` is:
7133
7134 .. math::
7135
7136 f(x, \nu) = \frac{\Gamma((\nu+1)/2)}
7137 {\sqrt{\pi \nu} \Gamma(\nu/2)}
7138 (1+x^2/\nu)^{-(\nu+1)/2}
7139
7140 where :math:`x` is a real number and the degrees of freedom parameter
7141 :math:`\nu` (denoted ``df`` in the implementation) satisfies
7142 :math:`\nu > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function
7143 (`scipy.special.gamma`).
7144
7145 %(after_notes)s
7146
7147 %(example)s
7148
7149 """
7150 def _shape_info(self):
7151 return [_ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
7152
7153 def _rvs(self, df, size=None, random_state=None):
7154 return random_state.standard_t(df, size=size)
7155
7156 def _pdf(self, x, df):
7157 return _lazywhere(
7158 df == np.inf, (x, df),
7159 f=lambda x, df: norm._pdf(x),
7160 f2=lambda x, df: (
7161 np.exp(self._logpdf(x, df))
7162 )
7163 )
7164
7165 def _logpdf(self, x, df):
7166
7167 def regular_formula(x, df):
7168 return (sc.gammaln((df + 1)/2) - sc.gammaln(df/2)
7169 - (0.5 * np.log(df*np.pi))
7170 - (df + 1)/2*np.log1p(x * x/df))
7171
7172 def asymptotic_formula(x, df):
7173 return (- 0.5 * (1 + np.log(2 * np.pi)) + df/2 * np.log1p(1/df)
7174 + 1/6 * (df + 1)**-1. - 1/45*(df + 1)**-3.
7175 - 1/6 * df**-1. + 1/45*df**-3.
7176 - (df + 1)/2 * np.log1p(x*x/df))
7177
7178 def norm_logpdf(x, df):
7179 return norm._logpdf(x)
7180
7181 return _lazyselect(
7182 ((df == np.inf),
7183 (df >= 200) & np.isfinite(df),
7184 (df < 200)),
7185 (norm_logpdf,
7186 asymptotic_formula,
7187 regular_formula),
7188 (x, df, )
7189 )
7190
7191 def _cdf(self, x, df):
7192 return sc.stdtr(df, x)
7193
7194 def _sf(self, x, df):
7195 return sc.stdtr(df, -x)
7196
7197 def _ppf(self, q, df):
7198 return sc.stdtrit(df, q)
7199
7200 def _isf(self, q, df):
7201 return -sc.stdtrit(df, q)
7202
7203 def _stats(self, df):
7204 # infinite df -> normal distribution (0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0)
7205 infinite_df = np.isposinf(df)
7206
7207 mu = np.where(df > 1, 0.0, np.inf)
7208
7209 condlist = ((df > 1) & (df <= 2),
7210 (df > 2) & np.isfinite(df),
7211 infinite_df)
7212 choicelist = (lambda df: np.broadcast_to(np.inf, df.shape),
7213 lambda df: df / (df-2.0),
7214 lambda df: np.broadcast_to(1, df.shape))
7215 mu2 = _lazyselect(condlist, choicelist, (df,), np.nan)
7216
7217 g1 = np.where(df > 3, 0.0, np.nan)
7218
7219 condlist = ((df > 2) & (df <= 4),
7220 (df > 4) & np.isfinite(df),
7221 infinite_df)
7222 choicelist = (lambda df: np.broadcast_to(np.inf, df.shape),
7223 lambda df: 6.0 / (df-4.0),
7224 lambda df: np.broadcast_to(0, df.shape))
7225 g2 = _lazyselect(condlist, choicelist, (df,), np.nan)
7226
7227 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
7228
7229 def _entropy(self, df):
7230 if df == np.inf:
7231 return norm._entropy()
7232
7233 def regular(df):
7234 half = df/2
7235 half1 = (df + 1)/2
7236 return (half1*(sc.digamma(half1) - sc.digamma(half))
7237 + np.log(np.sqrt(df)*sc.beta(half, 0.5)))
7238
7239 def asymptotic(df):
7240 # Formula from Wolfram Alpha:
7241 # "asymptotic expansion (d+1)/2 * (digamma((d+1)/2) - digamma(d/2))
7242 # + log(sqrt(d) * beta(d/2, 1/2))"
7243 h = (norm._entropy() + 1/df + (df**-2.)/4 - (df**-3.)/6
7244 - (df**-4.)/8 + 3/10*(df**-5.) + (df**-6.)/4)
7245 return h
7246
7247 h = _lazywhere(df >= 100, (df, ), f=asymptotic, f2=regular)
7248 return h
7249
7250
7251t = t_gen(name='t')
7252
7253
7254class nct_gen(rv_continuous):
7255 r"""A non-central Student's t continuous random variable.
7256
7257 %(before_notes)s
7258
7259 Notes
7260 -----
7261 If :math:`Y` is a standard normal random variable and :math:`V` is
7262 an independent chi-square random variable (`chi2`) with :math:`k` degrees
7263 of freedom, then
7264
7265 .. math::
7266
7267 X = \frac{Y + c}{\sqrt{V/k}}
7268
7269 has a non-central Student's t distribution on the real line.
7270 The degrees of freedom parameter :math:`k` (denoted ``df`` in the
7271 implementation) satisfies :math:`k > 0` and the noncentrality parameter
7272 :math:`c` (denoted ``nc`` in the implementation) is a real number.
7273
7274 %(after_notes)s
7275
7276 %(example)s
7277
7278 """
7279 def _argcheck(self, df, nc):
7280 return (df > 0) & (nc == nc)
7281
7282 def _shape_info(self):
7283 idf = _ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
7284 inc = _ShapeInfo("nc", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
7285 return [idf, inc]
7286
7287 def _rvs(self, df, nc, size=None, random_state=None):
7288 n = norm.rvs(loc=nc, size=size, random_state=random_state)
7289 c2 = chi2.rvs(df, size=size, random_state=random_state)
7290 return n * np.sqrt(df) / np.sqrt(c2)
7291
7292 def _pdf(self, x, df, nc):
7293 # Boost version has accuracy issues in left tail; see gh-16591
7294 n = df*1.0
7295 nc = nc*1.0
7296 x2 = x*x
7297 ncx2 = nc*nc*x2
7298 fac1 = n + x2
7299 trm1 = (n/2.*np.log(n) + sc.gammaln(n+1)
7300 - (n*np.log(2) + nc*nc/2 + (n/2)*np.log(fac1)
7301 + sc.gammaln(n/2)))
7302 Px = np.exp(trm1)
7303 valF = ncx2 / (2*fac1)
7304 trm1 = (np.sqrt(2)*nc*x*sc.hyp1f1(n/2+1, 1.5, valF)
7305 / np.asarray(fac1*sc.gamma((n+1)/2)))
7306 trm2 = (sc.hyp1f1((n+1)/2, 0.5, valF)
7307 / np.asarray(np.sqrt(fac1)*sc.gamma(n/2+1)))
7308 Px *= trm1+trm2
7309 return np.clip(Px, 0, None)
7310
7311 def _cdf(self, x, df, nc):
7312 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7313 return np.clip(_boost._nct_cdf(x, df, nc), 0, 1)
7314
7315 def _ppf(self, q, df, nc):
7316 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7317 return _boost._nct_ppf(q, df, nc)
7318
7319 def _sf(self, x, df, nc):
7320 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7321 return np.clip(_boost._nct_sf(x, df, nc), 0, 1)
7322
7323 def _isf(self, x, df, nc):
7324 with np.errstate(over='ignore'): # see gh-17432
7325 return _boost._nct_isf(x, df, nc)
7326
7327 def _stats(self, df, nc, moments='mv'):
7328 mu = _boost._nct_mean(df, nc)
7329 mu2 = _boost._nct_variance(df, nc)
7330 g1 = _boost._nct_skewness(df, nc) if 's' in moments else None
7331 g2 = _boost._nct_kurtosis_excess(df, nc) if 'k' in moments else None
7332 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
7333
7334
7335nct = nct_gen(name="nct")
7336
7337
7338class pareto_gen(rv_continuous):
7339 r"""A Pareto continuous random variable.
7340
7341 %(before_notes)s
7342
7343 Notes
7344 -----
7345 The probability density function for `pareto` is:
7346
7347 .. math::
7348
7349 f(x, b) = \frac{b}{x^{b+1}}
7350
7351 for :math:`x \ge 1`, :math:`b > 0`.
7352
7353 `pareto` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`.
7354
7355 %(after_notes)s
7356
7357 %(example)s
7358
7359 """
7360 def _shape_info(self):
7361 return [_ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
7362
7363 def _pdf(self, x, b):
7364 # pareto.pdf(x, b) = b / x**(b+1)
7365 return b * x**(-b-1)
7366
7367 def _cdf(self, x, b):
7368 return 1 - x**(-b)
7369
7370 def _ppf(self, q, b):
7371 return pow(1-q, -1.0/b)
7372
7373 def _sf(self, x, b):
7374 return x**(-b)
7375
7376 def _stats(self, b, moments='mv'):
7377 mu, mu2, g1, g2 = None, None, None, None
7378 if 'm' in moments:
7379 mask = b > 1
7380 bt = np.extract(mask, b)
7381 mu = np.full(np.shape(b), fill_value=np.inf)
7382 np.place(mu, mask, bt / (bt-1.0))
7383 if 'v' in moments:
7384 mask = b > 2
7385 bt = np.extract(mask, b)
7386 mu2 = np.full(np.shape(b), fill_value=np.inf)
7387 np.place(mu2, mask, bt / (bt-2.0) / (bt-1.0)**2)
7388 if 's' in moments:
7389 mask = b > 3
7390 bt = np.extract(mask, b)
7391 g1 = np.full(np.shape(b), fill_value=np.nan)
7392 vals = 2 * (bt + 1.0) * np.sqrt(bt - 2.0) / ((bt - 3.0) * np.sqrt(bt))
7393 np.place(g1, mask, vals)
7394 if 'k' in moments:
7395 mask = b > 4
7396 bt = np.extract(mask, b)
7397 g2 = np.full(np.shape(b), fill_value=np.nan)
7398 vals = (6.0*np.polyval([1.0, 1.0, -6, -2], bt) /
7399 np.polyval([1.0, -7.0, 12.0, 0.0], bt))
7400 np.place(g2, mask, vals)
7401 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
7402
7403 def _entropy(self, c):
7404 return 1 + 1.0/c - np.log(c)
7405
7406 @_call_super_mom
7407 @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
7408 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
7409 parameters = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data, args, kwds)
7410 data, fshape, floc, fscale = parameters
7411
7412 # ensure that any fixed parameters don't violate constraints of the
7413 # distribution before continuing.
7414 if floc is not None and np.min(data) - floc < (fscale or 0):
7415 raise FitDataError("pareto", lower=1, upper=np.inf)
7416
7417 ndata = data.shape[0]
7418
7419 def get_shape(scale, location):
7420 # The first-order necessary condition on `shape` can be solved in
7421 # closed form
7422 return ndata / np.sum(np.log((data - location) / scale))
7423
7424 if floc is fscale is None:
7425 # The support of the distribution is `(x - loc)/scale > 0`.
7426 # The method of Lagrange multipliers turns this constraint
7427 # into an equation that can be solved numerically.
7428 # See gh-12545 for details.
7429
7430 def dL_dScale(shape, scale):
7431 # The partial derivative of the log-likelihood function w.r.t.
7432 # the scale.
7433 return ndata * shape / scale
7434
7435 def dL_dLocation(shape, location):
7436 # The partial derivative of the log-likelihood function w.r.t.
7437 # the location.
7438 return (shape + 1) * np.sum(1 / (data - location))
7439
7440 def fun_to_solve(scale):
7441 # optimize the scale by setting the partial derivatives
7442 # w.r.t. to location and scale equal and solving.
7443 location = np.min(data) - scale
7444 shape = fshape or get_shape(scale, location)
7445 return dL_dLocation(shape, location) - dL_dScale(shape, scale)
7446
7447 def interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack):
7448 # return true if the signs disagree.
7449 return (np.sign(fun_to_solve(lbrack)) !=
7450 np.sign(fun_to_solve(rbrack)))
7451
7452 # set brackets for `root_scalar` to use when optimizing over the
7453 # scale such that a root is likely between them. Use user supplied
7454 # guess or default 1.
7455 brack_start = float(kwds.get('scale', 1))
7456 lbrack, rbrack = brack_start / 2, brack_start * 2
7457 # if a root is not between the brackets, iteratively expand them
7458 # until they include a sign change, checking after each bracket is
7459 # modified.
7460 while (not interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack)
7461 and (lbrack > 0 or rbrack < np.inf)):
7462 lbrack /= 2
7463 rbrack *= 2
7464 res = root_scalar(fun_to_solve, bracket=[lbrack, rbrack])
7465 if res.converged:
7466 scale = res.root
7467 loc = np.min(data) - scale
7468 shape = fshape or get_shape(scale, loc)
7469
7470 # The Pareto distribution requires that its parameters satisfy
7471 # the condition `fscale + floc <= min(data)`. However, to
7472 # avoid numerical issues, we require that `fscale + floc`
7473 # is strictly less than `min(data)`. If this condition
7474 # is not satisfied, reduce the scale with `np.nextafter` to
7475 # ensure that data does not fall outside of the support.
7476 if not (scale + loc) < np.min(data):
7477 scale = np.min(data) - loc
7478 scale = np.nextafter(scale, 0)
7479 return shape, loc, scale
7480 else:
7481 return super().fit(data, **kwds)
7482 elif floc is None:
7483 loc = np.min(data) - fscale
7484 else:
7485 loc = floc
7486 # Source: Evans, Hastings, and Peacock (2000), Statistical
7487 # Distributions, 3rd. Ed., John Wiley and Sons. Page 149.
7488 scale = fscale or np.min(data) - loc
7489 shape = fshape or get_shape(scale, loc)
7490 return shape, loc, scale
7491
7492
7493pareto = pareto_gen(a=1.0, name="pareto")
7494
7495
7496class lomax_gen(rv_continuous):
7497 r"""A Lomax (Pareto of the second kind) continuous random variable.
7498
7499 %(before_notes)s
7500
7501 Notes
7502 -----
7503 The probability density function for `lomax` is:
7504
7505 .. math::
7506
7507 f(x, c) = \frac{c}{(1+x)^{c+1}}
7508
7509 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`c > 0`.
7510
7511 `lomax` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
7512
7513 `lomax` is a special case of `pareto` with ``loc=-1.0``.
7514
7515 %(after_notes)s
7516
7517 %(example)s
7518
7519 """
7520 def _shape_info(self):
7521 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
7522
7523 def _pdf(self, x, c):
7524 # lomax.pdf(x, c) = c / (1+x)**(c+1)
7525 return c*1.0/(1.0+x)**(c+1.0)
7526
7527 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
7528 return np.log(c) - (c+1)*sc.log1p(x)
7529
7530 def _cdf(self, x, c):
7531 return -sc.expm1(-c*sc.log1p(x))
7532
7533 def _sf(self, x, c):
7534 return np.exp(-c*sc.log1p(x))
7535
7536 def _logsf(self, x, c):
7537 return -c*sc.log1p(x)
7538
7539 def _ppf(self, q, c):
7540 return sc.expm1(-sc.log1p(-q)/c)
7541
7542 def _stats(self, c):
7543 mu, mu2, g1, g2 = pareto.stats(c, loc=-1.0, moments='mvsk')
7544 return mu, mu2, g1, g2
7545
7546 def _entropy(self, c):
7547 return 1+1.0/c-np.log(c)
7548
7549
7550lomax = lomax_gen(a=0.0, name="lomax")
7551
7552
7553class pearson3_gen(rv_continuous):
7554 r"""A pearson type III continuous random variable.
7555
7556 %(before_notes)s
7557
7558 Notes
7559 -----
7560 The probability density function for `pearson3` is:
7561
7562 .. math::
7563
7564 f(x, \kappa) = \frac{|\beta|}{\Gamma(\alpha)}
7565 (\beta (x - \zeta))^{\alpha - 1}
7566 \exp(-\beta (x - \zeta))
7567
7568 where:
7569
7570 .. math::
7571
7572 \beta = \frac{2}{\kappa}
7573
7574 \alpha = \beta^2 = \frac{4}{\kappa^2}
7575
7576 \zeta = -\frac{\alpha}{\beta} = -\beta
7577
7578 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`).
7579 Pass the skew :math:`\kappa` into `pearson3` as the shape parameter
7580 ``skew``.
7581
7582 %(after_notes)s
7583
7584 %(example)s
7585
7586 References
7587 ----------
7588 R.W. Vogel and D.E. McMartin, "Probability Plot Goodness-of-Fit and
7589 Skewness Estimation Procedures for the Pearson Type 3 Distribution", Water
7590 Resources Research, Vol.27, 3149-3158 (1991).
7591
7592 L.R. Salvosa, "Tables of Pearson's Type III Function", Ann. Math. Statist.,
7593 Vol.1, 191-198 (1930).
7594
7595 "Using Modern Computing Tools to Fit the Pearson Type III Distribution to
7596 Aviation Loads Data", Office of Aviation Research (2003).
7597
7598 """
7599 def _preprocess(self, x, skew):
7600 # The real 'loc' and 'scale' are handled in the calling pdf(...). The
7601 # local variables 'loc' and 'scale' within pearson3._pdf are set to
7602 # the defaults just to keep them as part of the equations for
7603 # documentation.
7604 loc = 0.0
7605 scale = 1.0
7606
7607 # If skew is small, return _norm_pdf. The divide between pearson3
7608 # and norm was found by brute force and is approximately a skew of
7609 # 0.000016. No one, I hope, would actually use a skew value even
7610 # close to this small.
7611 norm2pearson_transition = 0.000016
7612
7613 ans, x, skew = np.broadcast_arrays(1.0, x, skew)
7614 ans = ans.copy()
7615
7616 # mask is True where skew is small enough to use the normal approx.
7617 mask = np.absolute(skew) < norm2pearson_transition
7618 invmask = ~mask
7619
7620 beta = 2.0 / (skew[invmask] * scale)
7621 alpha = (scale * beta)**2
7622 zeta = loc - alpha / beta
7623
7624 transx = beta * (x[invmask] - zeta)
7625 return ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta
7626
7627 def _argcheck(self, skew):
7628 # The _argcheck function in rv_continuous only allows positive
7629 # arguments. The skew argument for pearson3 can be zero (which I want
7630 # to handle inside pearson3._pdf) or negative. So just return True
7631 # for all skew args.
7632 return np.isfinite(skew)
7633
7634 def _shape_info(self):
7635 return [_ShapeInfo("skew", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))]
7636
7637 def _stats(self, skew):
7638 m = 0.0
7639 v = 1.0
7640 s = skew
7641 k = 1.5*skew**2
7642 return m, v, s, k
7643
7644 def _pdf(self, x, skew):
7645 # pearson3.pdf(x, skew) = abs(beta) / gamma(alpha) *
7646 # (beta * (x - zeta))**(alpha - 1) * exp(-beta*(x - zeta))
7647 # Do the calculation in _logpdf since helps to limit
7648 # overflow/underflow problems
7649 ans = np.exp(self._logpdf(x, skew))
7650 if ans.ndim == 0:
7651 if np.isnan(ans):
7652 return 0.0
7653 return ans
7654 ans[np.isnan(ans)] = 0.0
7655 return ans
7656
7657 def _logpdf(self, x, skew):
7658 # PEARSON3 logpdf GAMMA logpdf
7659 # np.log(abs(beta))
7660 # + (alpha - 1)*np.log(beta*(x - zeta)) + (a - 1)*np.log(x)
7661 # - beta*(x - zeta) - x
7662 # - sc.gammalnalpha) - sc.gammalna)
7663 ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, _ = (
7664 self._preprocess(x, skew))
7665
7666 ans[mask] = np.log(_norm_pdf(x[mask]))
7667 # use logpdf instead of _logpdf to fix issue mentioned in gh-12640
7668 # (_logpdf does not return correct result for alpha = 1)
7669 ans[invmask] = np.log(abs(beta)) + gamma.logpdf(transx, alpha)
7670 return ans
7671
7672 def _cdf(self, x, skew):
7673 ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, _, alpha, _ = (
7674 self._preprocess(x, skew))
7675
7676 ans[mask] = _norm_cdf(x[mask])
7677
7678 skew = np.broadcast_to(skew, invmask.shape)
7679 invmask1a = np.logical_and(invmask, skew > 0)
7680 invmask1b = skew[invmask] > 0
7681 # use cdf instead of _cdf to fix issue mentioned in gh-12640
7682 # (_cdf produces NaNs for inputs outside support)
7683 ans[invmask1a] = gamma.cdf(transx[invmask1b], alpha[invmask1b])
7684
7685 # The gamma._cdf approach wasn't working with negative skew.
7686 # Note that multiplying the skew by -1 reflects about x=0.
7687 # So instead of evaluating the CDF with negative skew at x,
7688 # evaluate the SF with positive skew at -x.
7689 invmask2a = np.logical_and(invmask, skew < 0)
7690 invmask2b = skew[invmask] < 0
7691 # gamma._sf produces NaNs when transx < 0, so use gamma.sf
7692 ans[invmask2a] = gamma.sf(transx[invmask2b], alpha[invmask2b])
7693
7694 return ans
7695
7696 def _rvs(self, skew, size=None, random_state=None):
7697 skew = np.broadcast_to(skew, size)
7698 ans, _, _, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta = (
7699 self._preprocess([0], skew))
7700
7701 nsmall = mask.sum()
7702 nbig = mask.size - nsmall
7703 ans[mask] = random_state.standard_normal(nsmall)
7704 ans[invmask] = random_state.standard_gamma(alpha, nbig)/beta + zeta
7705
7706 if size == ():
7707 ans = ans[0]
7708 return ans
7709
7710 def _ppf(self, q, skew):
7711 ans, q, _, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta = (
7712 self._preprocess(q, skew))
7713 ans[mask] = _norm_ppf(q[mask])
7714 q = q[invmask]
7715 q[beta < 0] = 1 - q[beta < 0] # for negative skew; see gh-17050
7716 ans[invmask] = sc.gammaincinv(alpha, q)/beta + zeta
7717 return ans
7718
7719 @_call_super_mom
7720 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
7721 Note that method of moments (`method='MM'`) is not
7722 available for this distribution.\n\n""")
7723 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
7724 if kwds.get("method", None) == 'MM':
7725 raise NotImplementedError("Fit `method='MM'` is not available for "
7726 "the Pearson3 distribution. Please try "
7727 "the default `method='MLE'`.")
7728 else:
7729 return super(type(self), self).fit(data, *args, **kwds)
7730
7731
7732pearson3 = pearson3_gen(name="pearson3")
7733
7734
7735class powerlaw_gen(rv_continuous):
7736 r"""A power-function continuous random variable.
7737
7738 %(before_notes)s
7739
7740 See Also
7741 --------
7742 pareto
7743
7744 Notes
7745 -----
7746 The probability density function for `powerlaw` is:
7747
7748 .. math::
7749
7750 f(x, a) = a x^{a-1}
7751
7752 for :math:`0 \le x \le 1`, :math:`a > 0`.
7753
7754 `powerlaw` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`.
7755
7756 %(after_notes)s
7757
7758 For example, the support of `powerlaw` can be adjusted from the default
7759 interval ``[0, 1]`` to the interval ``[c, c+d]`` by setting ``loc=c`` and
7760 ``scale=d``. For a power-law distribution with infinite support, see
7761 `pareto`.
7762
7763 `powerlaw` is a special case of `beta` with ``b=1``.
7764
7765 %(example)s
7766
7767 """
7768 def _shape_info(self):
7769 return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
7770
7771 def _pdf(self, x, a):
7772 # powerlaw.pdf(x, a) = a * x**(a-1)
7773 return a*x**(a-1.0)
7774
7775 def _logpdf(self, x, a):
7776 return np.log(a) + sc.xlogy(a - 1, x)
7777
7778 def _cdf(self, x, a):
7779 return x**(a*1.0)
7780
7781 def _logcdf(self, x, a):
7782 return a*np.log(x)
7783
7784 def _ppf(self, q, a):
7785 return pow(q, 1.0/a)
7786
7787 def _sf(self, p, a):
7788 return -sc.powm1(p, a)
7789
7790 def _stats(self, a):
7791 return (a / (a + 1.0),
7792 a / (a + 2.0) / (a + 1.0) ** 2,
7793 -2.0 * ((a - 1.0) / (a + 3.0)) * np.sqrt((a + 2.0) / a),
7794 6 * np.polyval([1, -1, -6, 2], a) / (a * (a + 3.0) * (a + 4)))
7795
7796 def _entropy(self, a):
7797 return 1 - 1.0/a - np.log(a)
7798
7799 def _support_mask(self, x, a):
7800 return (super()._support_mask(x, a)
7801 & ((x != 0) | (a >= 1)))
7802
7803 @_call_super_mom
7804 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\
7805 Notes specifically for ``powerlaw.fit``: If the location is a free
7806 parameter and the value returned for the shape parameter is less than
7807 one, the true maximum likelihood approaches infinity. This causes
7808 numerical difficulties, and the resulting estimates are approximate.
7809 \n\n""")
7810 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
7811 # Summary of the strategy:
7812 #
7813 # 1) If the scale and location are fixed, return the shape according
7814 # to a formula.
7815 #
7816 # 2) If the scale is fixed, there are two possibilities for the other
7817 # parameters - one corresponding with shape less than one, and
7818 # another with shape greater than one. Calculate both, and return
7819 # whichever has the better log-likelihood.
7820 #
7821 # At this point, the scale is known to be free.
7822 #
7823 # 3) If the location is fixed, return the scale and shape according to
7824 # formulas (or, if the shape is fixed, the fixed shape).
7825 #
7826 # At this point, the location and scale are both free. There are
7827 # separate equations depending on whether the shape is less than one or
7828 # greater than one.
7829 #
7830 # 4a) If the shape is less than one, there are formulas for shape,
7831 # location, and scale.
7832 # 4b) If the shape is greater than one, there are formulas for shape
7833 # and scale, but there is a condition for location to be solved
7834 # numerically.
7835 #
7836 # If the shape is fixed and less than one, we use 4a.
7837 # If the shape is fixed and greater than one, we use 4b.
7838 # If the shape is also free, we calculate fits using both 4a and 4b
7839 # and choose the one that results a better log-likelihood.
7840 #
7841 # In many cases, the use of `np.nextafter` is used to avoid numerical
7842 # issues.
7843 if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
7844 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
7845
7846 if len(np.unique(data)) == 1:
7847 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
7848
7849 data, fshape, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
7850 args, kwds)
7851 penalized_nllf_args = [data, (self._fitstart(data),)]
7852 penalized_nllf = self._reduce_func(penalized_nllf_args, {})[1]
7853
7854 # ensure that any fixed parameters don't violate constraints of the
7855 # distribution before continuing. The support of the distribution
7856 # is `0 < (x - loc)/scale < 1`.
7857 if floc is not None:
7858 if not data.min() > floc:
7859 raise FitDataError('powerlaw', 0, 1)
7860 if fscale is not None and not data.max() <= floc + fscale:
7861 raise FitDataError('powerlaw', 0, 1)
7862
7863 if fscale is not None:
7864 if fscale <= 0:
7865 raise ValueError("Negative or zero `fscale` is outside the "
7866 "range allowed by the distribution.")
7867 if fscale <= data.ptp():
7868 msg = "`fscale` must be greater than the range of data."
7869 raise ValueError(msg)
7870
7871 def get_shape(data, loc, scale):
7872 # The first-order necessary condition on `shape` can be solved in
7873 # closed form. It can be used no matter the assumption of the
7874 # value of the shape.
7875 N = len(data)
7876 return - N / (np.sum(np.log(data - loc)) - N*np.log(scale))
7877
7878 def get_scale(data, loc):
7879 # analytical solution for `scale` based on the location.
7880 # It can be used no matter the assumption of the value of the
7881 # shape.
7882 return data.max() - loc
7883
7884 # 1) The location and scale are both fixed. Analytically determine the
7885 # shape.
7886 if fscale is not None and floc is not None:
7887 return get_shape(data, floc, fscale), floc, fscale
7888
7889 # 2) The scale is fixed. There are two possibilities for the other
7890 # parameters. Choose the option with better log-likelihood.
7891 if fscale is not None:
7892 # using `data.min()` as the optimal location
7893 loc_lt1 = np.nextafter(data.min(), -np.inf)
7894 shape_lt1 = fshape or get_shape(data, loc_lt1, fscale)
7895 ll_lt1 = penalized_nllf((shape_lt1, loc_lt1, fscale), data)
7896
7897 # using `data.max() - scale` as the optimal location
7898 loc_gt1 = np.nextafter(data.max() - fscale, np.inf)
7899 shape_gt1 = fshape or get_shape(data, loc_gt1, fscale)
7900 ll_gt1 = penalized_nllf((shape_gt1, loc_gt1, fscale), data)
7901
7902 if ll_lt1 < ll_gt1:
7903 return shape_lt1, loc_lt1, fscale
7904 else:
7905 return shape_gt1, loc_gt1, fscale
7906
7907 # 3) The location is fixed. Return the analytical scale and the
7908 # analytical (or fixed) shape.
7909 if floc is not None:
7910 scale = get_scale(data, floc)
7911 shape = fshape or get_shape(data, floc, scale)
7912 return shape, floc, scale
7913
7914 # 4) Location and scale are both free
7915 # 4a) Use formulas that assume `shape <= 1`.
7916
7917 def fit_loc_scale_w_shape_lt_1():
7918 loc = np.nextafter(data.min(), -np.inf)
7919 if np.abs(loc) < np.finfo(loc.dtype).tiny:
7920 loc = np.sign(loc) * np.finfo(loc.dtype).tiny
7921 scale = np.nextafter(get_scale(data, loc), np.inf)
7922 shape = fshape or get_shape(data, loc, scale)
7923 return shape, loc, scale
7924
7925 # 4b) Fit under the assumption that `shape > 1`. The support
7926 # of the distribution is `(x - loc)/scale <= 1`. The method of Lagrange
7927 # multipliers turns this constraint into the condition that
7928 # dL_dScale - dL_dLocation must be zero, which is solved numerically.
7929 # (Alternatively, substitute the constraint into the objective
7930 # function before deriving the likelihood equation for location.)
7931
7932 def dL_dScale(data, shape, scale):
7933 # The partial derivative of the log-likelihood function w.r.t.
7934 # the scale.
7935 return -data.shape[0] * shape / scale
7936
7937 def dL_dLocation(data, shape, loc):
7938 # The partial derivative of the log-likelihood function w.r.t.
7939 # the location.
7940 return (shape - 1) * np.sum(1 / (loc - data)) # -1/(data-loc)
7941
7942 def dL_dLocation_star(loc):
7943 # The derivative of the log-likelihood function w.r.t.
7944 # the location, given optimal shape and scale
7945 scale = np.nextafter(get_scale(data, loc), -np.inf)
7946 shape = fshape or get_shape(data, loc, scale)
7947 return dL_dLocation(data, shape, loc)
7948
7949 def fun_to_solve(loc):
7950 # optimize the location by setting the partial derivatives
7951 # w.r.t. to location and scale equal and solving.
7952 scale = np.nextafter(get_scale(data, loc), -np.inf)
7953 shape = fshape or get_shape(data, loc, scale)
7954 return (dL_dScale(data, shape, scale)
7955 - dL_dLocation(data, shape, loc))
7956
7957 def fit_loc_scale_w_shape_gt_1():
7958 # set brackets for `root_scalar` to use when optimizing over the
7959 # location such that a root is likely between them.
7960 rbrack = np.nextafter(data.min(), -np.inf)
7961
7962 # if the sign of `dL_dLocation_star` is positive at rbrack,
7963 # we're not going to find the root we're looking for
7964 delta = (data.min() - rbrack)
7965 while dL_dLocation_star(rbrack) > 0:
7966 rbrack = data.min() - delta
7967 delta *= 2
7968
7969 def interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack):
7970 # Check if the interval (lbrack, rbrack) contains the root.
7971 return (np.sign(fun_to_solve(lbrack))
7972 != np.sign(fun_to_solve(rbrack)))
7973
7974 lbrack = rbrack - 1
7975
7976 # if the sign doesn't change between the brackets, move the left
7977 # bracket until it does. (The right bracket remains fixed at the
7978 # maximum permissible value.)
7979 i = 1.0
7980 while (not interval_contains_root(lbrack, rbrack)
7981 and lbrack != -np.inf):
7982 lbrack = (data.min() - i)
7983 i *= 2
7984
7985 root = optimize.root_scalar(fun_to_solve, bracket=(lbrack, rbrack))
7986
7987 loc = np.nextafter(root.root, -np.inf)
7988 scale = np.nextafter(get_scale(data, loc), np.inf)
7989 shape = fshape or get_shape(data, loc, scale)
7990 return shape, loc, scale
7991
7992 # Shape is fixed - choose 4a or 4b accordingly.
7993 if fshape is not None and fshape <= 1:
7994 return fit_loc_scale_w_shape_lt_1()
7995 elif fshape is not None and fshape > 1:
7996 return fit_loc_scale_w_shape_gt_1()
7997
7998 # Shape is free
7999 fit_shape_lt1 = fit_loc_scale_w_shape_lt_1()
8000 ll_lt1 = self.nnlf(fit_shape_lt1, data)
8001
8002 fit_shape_gt1 = fit_loc_scale_w_shape_gt_1()
8003 ll_gt1 = self.nnlf(fit_shape_gt1, data)
8004
8005 if ll_lt1 <= ll_gt1 and fit_shape_lt1[0] <= 1:
8006 return fit_shape_lt1
8007 elif ll_lt1 > ll_gt1 and fit_shape_gt1[0] > 1:
8008 return fit_shape_gt1
8009 else:
8010 return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
8011
8012
8013powerlaw = powerlaw_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name="powerlaw")
8014
8015
8016class powerlognorm_gen(rv_continuous):
8017 r"""A power log-normal continuous random variable.
8018
8019 %(before_notes)s
8020
8021 Notes
8022 -----
8023 The probability density function for `powerlognorm` is:
8024
8025 .. math::
8026
8027 f(x, c, s) = \frac{c}{x s} \phi(\log(x)/s)
8028 (\Phi(-\log(x)/s))^{c-1}
8029
8030 where :math:`\phi` is the normal pdf, and :math:`\Phi` is the normal cdf,
8031 and :math:`x > 0`, :math:`s, c > 0`.
8032
8033 `powerlognorm` takes :math:`c` and :math:`s` as shape parameters.
8034
8035 %(after_notes)s
8036
8037 %(example)s
8038
8039 """
8040 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
8041
8042 def _shape_info(self):
8043 ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
8044 i_s = _ShapeInfo("s", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
8045 return [ic, i_s]
8046
8047 def _pdf(self, x, c, s):
8048 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c, s))
8049
8050 def _logpdf(self, x, c, s):
8051 return (np.log(c) - np.log(x) - np.log(s) +
8052 _norm_logpdf(np.log(x) / s) +
8053 _norm_logcdf(-np.log(x) / s) * (c - 1.))
8054
8055 def _cdf(self, x, c, s):
8056 return -sc.expm1(self._logsf(x, c, s))
8057
8058 def _ppf(self, q, c, s):
8059 return self._isf(1 - q, c, s)
8060
8061 def _sf(self, x, c, s):
8062 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c, s))
8063
8064 def _logsf(self, x, c, s):
8065 return _norm_logcdf(-np.log(x) / s) * c
8066
8067 def _isf(self, q, c, s):
8068 return np.exp(-_norm_ppf(q**(1/c)) * s)
8069
8070
8071powerlognorm = powerlognorm_gen(a=0.0, name="powerlognorm")
8072
8073
8074class powernorm_gen(rv_continuous):
8075 r"""A power normal continuous random variable.
8076
8077 %(before_notes)s
8078
8079 Notes
8080 -----
8081 The probability density function for `powernorm` is:
8082
8083 .. math::
8084
8085 f(x, c) = c \phi(x) (\Phi(-x))^{c-1}
8086
8087 where :math:`\phi` is the normal pdf, :math:`\Phi` is the normal cdf,
8088 :math:`x` is any real, and :math:`c > 0` [1]_.
8089
8090 `powernorm` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`.
8091
8092 %(after_notes)s
8093
8094 References
8095 ----------
8096 .. [1] NIST Engineering Statistics Handbook, Section 1.3.6.6.13,
8097 https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook//eda/section3/eda366d.htm
8098
8099 %(example)s
8100
8101 """
8102 def _shape_info(self):
8103 return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
8104
8105 def _pdf(self, x, c):
8106 # powernorm.pdf(x, c) = c * phi(x) * (Phi(-x))**(c-1)
8107 return c*_norm_pdf(x) * (_norm_cdf(-x)**(c-1.0))
8108
8109 def _logpdf(self, x, c):
8110 return np.log(c) + _norm_logpdf(x) + (c-1)*_norm_logcdf(-x)
8111
8112 def _cdf(self, x, c):
8113 return -sc.expm1(self._logsf(x, c))
8114
8115 def _ppf(self, q, c):
8116 return -_norm_ppf(pow(1.0 - q, 1.0 / c))
8117
8118 def _sf(self, x, c):
8119 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c))
8120
8121 def _logsf(self, x, c):
8122 return c * _norm_logcdf(-x)
8123
8124 def _isf(self, q, c):
8125 return -_norm_ppf(np.exp(np.log(q) / c))
8126
8127
8128powernorm = powernorm_gen(name='powernorm')
8129
8130
8131class rdist_gen(rv_continuous):
8132 r"""An R-distributed (symmetric beta) continuous random variable.
8133
8134 %(before_notes)s
8135
8136 Notes
8137 -----
8138 The probability density function for `rdist` is:
8139
8140 .. math::
8141
8142 f(x, c) = \frac{(1-x^2)^{c/2-1}}{B(1/2, c/2)}
8143
8144 for :math:`-1 \le x \le 1`, :math:`c > 0`. `rdist` is also called the
8145 symmetric beta distribution: if B has a `beta` distribution with
